before i eat my way around catalonia i assume that the great and sadly late penelope casas recipe for romesco sauce from her book the foods and wines of spain be the only one i would ever need

it ' marvelous on simply cook fish tasty stir into seafood stew and make a fine top for pretty much any vegetable sturdy enough to hold its own against the thick pungent sauce

the u.s. federal reserve remain the most powerful central bank in the world
its policy action reverberate in every corner of the globe something no other central bank can claim
even the hint of a taper the withdrawal of easy money policy have roil emerge market
the prospect of rise interest rate in the united states have lead investor to pull back from risky investment in those country
emerge market like brazil india and indonesia be face plunge currency and decline stock market
low interest rate in the united states have lead investor to look to emerge market for better return on their money fuel boom in equity and real estate market as well as high inflation in some country
for the previous two year emerge market have be complain about how these inflow fuel by cheap money in the united states cause their currency to appreciate too rapidly hurt their export competitiveness
the fact that those same currency be now tumble have lead to the opposite complaint that the fed should back off more slowly from its earlier policy and better communicate its intention to financial market
give the global impact of the fed 's action the choice of a replacement for ben bernanke as chairman of the federal reserve be be watch with keen interest
no matter who be choose there be important change in store for central bank and financial market the world over
despite the global economic crisis financial market be now more closely connect then ever before
china india and other major economy have continue remove restriction to capital flow open up their market to cross border investment
give this increased mobility action by any of the major central bank have effect well beyond their own national border
moreover in the aftermath of the crisis central bank have become even more important to economic management take on much of the burden of control inflation improve financial stability and promote growth
this be a difficult balancing act in the best of time
it become virtually impossible when fiscal and other policy be work at cross purpose
in the united states for instance short term fiscal tightening along with the uncertainty associate with deficit and debt ceiling negotiation that repeatedly go down to the wire have hobble the recovery
meanwhile little have be do to tackle the long term fiscal problem especially entitlement spending
the focus on short term austerity have limit productivity enhance expenditure in such area as infrastructure and education
in india the government have be unwilling to undertake politically unpopular reform to tackle large budget deficit and structural problem such as stifle labor market regulation
this have leave it to the maker of monetary policy to do all the heavy lifting
other emerge market face similar issue
the reliance on central bank to make up for the failing of other policy have create inevitable international tension
the right monetary policy for one country may not necessarily be what be good for another
unlike fiscal policy whose effect tend to stay mostly domestic monetary policy do affect currency value and financial market in other country through cross border financial flow
whoever take over from bernanke the reality be that the fed chairman have a mandate to focus only on domestic objective
fair enough no central bank in the world have anything but domestic objective in its mandate
but when the fed act it matter to the world in a way that no other central bank 's action do
in a report by a committee of academic and former central banker in which i participate we argue that the fed and a small group of central bank from both advance and emerge market economy should hold regular meeting and issue a report on their monetary policy intention
even if this procedure only expose mutual inconsistency in policy it would be a way to bring broad pressure on politician to stop rely on the crutch of monetary policy and prod them to take politically unpopular measure to improve productivity and the prospect of long term growth while make global capital flow more stable
so who would the rest of the world vote for to head the most important central bank
now that lawrence summers have withdraw from the race the presumptive front runner be janet yellen
many central banker view her as someone who be empathetic to the spillover effect of u.s. policy someone who have enough credibility to soothe financial market and ably steer the fed
in any event no matter who get the job what many of the world 's central banker be hop for be a fed that can go back to the more mod objective of maintain low inflation and financial stability
on that at least there be certainly international agreement

winter squash already sweet and caramelize from roasting make as delicious a partner for miso glaze as eggplant 1 large butternut squash about 2 pound salt to taste 2 tablespoon dark sesame oil 1 tablespoon mirin 1 tablespoon sake 2 tablespoon white or yellow miso 1 tablespoon sugar 1
preheat the oven to 425 degree
line a baking sheet or 2 if necessary with parchment
peel the squash cut in half and scrape out the seed and fiber
slice 1/2 inch thick and place in a large bowl
season with a little salt if desire and toss with 1 1/2 tablespoon of the sesame oil
lay the slice in one layer on the baking sheet( 2
roast the squash for 25 to 30 minute turn the slice over every 10 minute until the slice be tender all the way through and lightly colored
3
meanwhile heat the broiler and make the glaze
to make the glaze combine the mirin and sake in the small saucepan you have and bring to a boil over high heat
boil 20 second take care not to boil off much of the liquid then turn the heat to low and stir in the miso and the sugar
whisk over medium low heat without let the mixture boil until the sugar have dissolve
remove from the heat and whisk in the sesame oil
4
remove the squash from the oven and brush each slice with the miso glaze
place under the broiler about 2 inch from the heat and broil for about 1 minute or until the glaze begin to bubble and look shiny
remove from the heat
allow to cool if desire or serve hot
yield serve 4 to 6 advance preparation this taste wonderful even a day after you make it
you can serve it cold or reheat

yield serve 4 advance preparation
you can prepare the fish 12 hour before cooking

a friend of mine never understand why his neighbor spend a lot of money on thing he do not care about like house and car
to him these thing be not worth the money
so one time when he be be particularly grumpy about it i ask him about his family 's spending habit
i have notice that compare with most family i know his family appear to spend a lot of money on vacation and even more on recreational gear
my friend be a smart guy take only a moment to see the disconnect
both my friend and his neighbor have make a decision that it be worth it to them to spend more on thing and experience that they really value
it ' not unusual to spend more money on the thing that really matter to us
we probably all have something we refuse to substitute for a cheap option
however when we do spend more without build a framework for make these decision it ' the kind of behavior that can blow up budget and lead us to spend more on thing that be not worth the extra money
here be a few thing to keep in mind 1
it make sense to spend more if we want something to last longer
a few year ago i have my eye on a new road bike
the bike i want be not cheap and i debate buy a less expensive option
but when i start weigh the purchase in term of want to ride the bike for year the more expensive better build bike make more sense
i still have and love the bike
time matter when we 're debate spend more
when we anticipate use something over a long period of time it ' important to compare the cost of replace a cheap version two or three time
if the cost be comparable the more expensive option could be the better choice
2
it make sense to spend more if we want rare specific experience
i imagine more than a few of you roll your eye when i share my love of expensive ice cream
part of the reason i enjoy it so much be the anticipation
i do not eat it often only once every few week
however the pleasure i get from anticipate that next pint be almost worth the price alone
i would not feel the same way if it be not a rare experience
so when you want to spend more on something specific remember to consider the value of anticipation and how often you plan on do it
the rare the event the great the anticipation and research show that anticipate a future event like a vacation can match or even beat the happiness of the event itself
it ' the rare two for one deal that make it worth spend more if we have make the smart decision to save and plan for it
3
it do not make sense to spend more if it ' not a priority
sometimes the generic be just as good as the brand
unlike my ice cream i rarely opt for the most expensive laundry soap
now some of you may be really particular about your laundry soap
the point be when we spend more we need to consider both reason 1 and 2 and if it ' a purchase that actually matter to us
if the option be interchangeable then go for a less expensive choice
do not get in the habit of spend more for the sake of spend more
4
it do not make sense to spend more if it ' about compete with people
my friend do not care about his neighbor car and house
for him spend more on vacation and gear he really want be what matter
so do not forget the phrase keep up with the joneses when decide what something be really worth
commit to spend more only on the thing and experience that matter personally
it do not matter what our neighbor or friend want
focus on what matter to you and your family and ignore what everyone else be do
spend a lot of money on something even something we would consider a luxury do not mean we 're make a bad money decision
it may even be the best decision
but to reach the point of know it ' a good decision we need to be really aware of why we want to spend more and do our best to align the decision with our value
the more we can make money decision that support our value the less likely we be to regret those decision even if they 're expensive choice
keep that thought in mind the next time you wonder if it ' really worth it to spend more
brace yourself sometimes the answer will be yes

q. why do lobster turn from dark blue green to red when boil
and why be they that dark color in the first place
a. a relatively simple explanation for the color change emerge in a study publish in 2002 heat change the shape of a protein call beta crustacyanin in the shell relax its bond with the pigment astaxanthin
the free pigment reflect wavelength of light in the red spectrum
but it turn out that the heat relate shape change account for only about a third of the color difference accord to a 2005 study by dutch researcher in the journal of the american chemical society
the new research point to a complex quantum physic interaction that would account for a much large shift and for the live lobster 's original color
when the red pigment be fully hide in the enclose protein it absorb all wavelength of light red as well as blue and green so the lobster appear black
the previous research have find that the red pigment molecule be group in pair within the crustacyanin cross each other in a tight x formation
the dutch researcher calculate that they interfere with one another cause shift in their quantum energy state thus alter the wavelength of light that be absorb
use nuclear magnetic resonance imaging and spectroscopy to examine protein pigment interaction the researcher find that this effect be a large one suggest that it be the primary source of lobster color.â â question@nytimes.com

long before he bring people into his laboratory at columbia university to smoke crack cocaine carl hart saw its effect firsthand
grow up in poverty he watch relative become crack addict live in squalor and steal from their mother
childhood friend end up in prison and morgue
those addict seem enslave by crack like the laboratory rat that could not stop press the lever for cocaine even as they be starve to death
the cocaine be provide such powerful dopamine stimulation to the brain 's reward center that the addict could not resist take another hit
at least that be how it look to dr. hart when he start his research career in the 1990
like other scientist he hop to find a neurological cure to addiction some mechanism for block that dopamine activity in the brain so that people would not succumb to the otherwise irresistible craving for cocaine heroin and other powerfully addictive drug
but then when he begin study addict he saw that drug be not so irresistible after all
eighty to 90 percent of people who use crack and methamphetamine do not get addicted say dr. hart an associate professor of psychology

and the small number who do become addicted be nothing like the popular caricature
dr. hart recruit addict by advertising in the village voice offer them a chance to make $ 950 while smoke crack make from pharmaceutical grade cocaine
most of the respondent like the addict he know grow up in miami be black man from low income neighborhood
to participate they have to live in a hospital ward for several week during the experiment
at the start of each day as researcher watch behind a one way mirror a nurse would place a certain amount of crack in a pipe the dose vary daily and light it
while smoking the participant be blindfold so he could not see the size of that day 's dose
then after that sample of crack to start the day each participant would be offer more opportunity during the day to smoke the same dose of crack
but each time the offer be make the participant could also opt for a different reward that they could collect when they eventually leave the hospital
sometimes the reward be $ 5 in cash and sometimes it be a $ 5 voucher for merchandise at a store
when the dose of crack be fairly high the subject would typically choose to keep smoke crack during the day
but when the dose be small he be more likely to pass it up for the $ 5 in cash or voucher
they do not fit the caricature of the drug addict who can not stop once he get a taste dr. hart say
when they be give an alternative to crack they make rational economic decision
when methamphetamine replace crack as the great drug scourge in the united states dr. hart bring meth addict into his laboratory for similar experiment and the result show similarly rational decision
he also find that when he raise the alternative reward to $ 20 every single addict of meth and crack alike choose the cash
they know they would not receive it until the experiment end week later but they be still willing to pass up an immediate high
these finding make dr. hart rethink what he would see grow up as he relate in his new book high price
it ' a fascinating combination of memoir and social science wrench scene of deprivation and violence accompany by calm analysis of historical data and laboratory result
he tell horrifying story his mother attack with a hammer his father douse with a potful of boil syrup but then he look for the statistically significant trend
yes he note some child be abandon by crack addict parent but many family in his neighborhood be tear apart before crack include his own
he be raise largely by his grandmother
yes his cousin become destitute crack addict live in a shed but they would drop out of school and have be unemployed long before crack come along
there seem to be at least as many if not more case in which illicit drug play little or no role than be there situation in which their pharmacological effect seem to matter write dr. hart now 46
crack and meth may be especially troublesome in some poor neighborhood and rural area but not because the drug themselves be so potent 1 2 next page

a.

you can also invite more guest add a video call or request a timed reminder from google so you remember the event yourself

click the send button to notify your guest of the change

as the egg divide to form an embryo it produce new copy of that original genome
for decade geneticist have explore how an embryo can use the instruction in a single genome to develop muscle nerve and the many other part of the human body

the road to japan 's energy future run through a cluster of low building in this city the large on the northern island of hokkaido
here work on their own and in collaboration with american scientist researcher be study sediment core contain methane hydrate icy construct of water molecule with the explosive ga methane trap within
hydrate contain sediment be find in large amount around the world both under the sea and to a less extent in permafrost
if they can be tap safely and economically they could be an abundant source of fuel especially for country like japan that have few energy reserve of their own
the japanese researcher work have already bear fruit in march the government announce that it have successfully produce methane from hydrate in sediment under the pacific ocean
the effort conduct from a drilling ship in the nankai trough about 100 mile east of osaka be the world 's first hydrate production test in deep water
but scientist say there be still much that be unknown about the unusual compound sometimes refer to as flammable ice and that the commercial production of ga from them be still far off
we need to know more about the physical property of hydrate themselves and of the sediment as well say hideo narita the director of the research laboratory part of the national institute of advanced industrial science and technology which be finance largely by the government
further research here and at lab around the world will help scientist better understand the environmental impact of hydrate production include the possible release of methane a potent greenhouse ga into the sea or atmosphere
there be also the potential for subsea landforms to become unstable when hydrate be remove
timothy s. collett a research geologist with the united states geological survey say that despite all the talk about their potential as an energy resource hydrate be largely still a scientific issue
the research pose special challenge because hydrate form under high pressure cause by the weight of all the seawater or rock above them and that pressure must be maintain when the sediment core be analyze
if it be not the hydrate within quickly dissociate into water and ga and the sediment look like chocolate mousse say carlos santamarina a professor at georgia tech

moscow american farmer be get an unexpected windfall from a contentious fight between russia and belarus a former soviet splinter state
the subject of the fight be potash a fertilizer
the score so far one imprison russian business executive the disintegration of a once effective cartel that keep world potash price high and political tension between the two country
what be be call the fertilizer war be the late of numerous trade and economic spat between russia and belarus whose leader though preside over similar autocratic political system do not get along personally russian political analyst say
aleksandr g. lukashenko president of belarus and vladimir v. putin president of russia by most account detest each another
their feeling have spill over into the fertilizer business
the potash problem reach a peak on july 30 when uralkali the russian potash company announce it be withdraw from an international cartel call the belarusian potash company or b.p.c. which be create to keep price high
two marketing group b.p.c. in the former soviet union and canpotex in canada sell nearly all the potash in the world
b.p.c. market fertilizer for uralkali and belaruskali the belarussian company and canpotex for three canadian producer the potash corporation of saskatchewan mosaic and agrium
for year potash company have keep a thumb on the global trade of this critical plant nutrient choke back supply to raise price much as the organization of the petroleum exporting countries do with oil or de beers with diamond
the two cartel set nearly identical price for potash worldwide prevent farmer from benefit from competition
uralkali say it be leave b.p.c. because the belarus president have be allow fertilizer sale on the side
it predict potash price would drop about 25 percent to $ 300 a ton from around $ 400 a ton when it leave
the low price would hurt russia but they would hurt belarus more
though uralkali deny any direct link this action come after year of effort by mr. putin and the kremlin to compel belarus to sell strategic asset like oil refinery and natural ga pipeline in exchange for subsidized energy supply
mr. lukashenko first agree to sell a stake in belaruskali though the potash mine provide about 10 percent of the state tax revenue but then balk
he say it be still for sale but cite an exorbitantly high price anger the russian oligarch who have be vie for it and set the stage for the breakup of the fertilizer cartel that follow
the belarussian government retaliate with what appear to be a trap the belarussian prime minister invite the chief executive of uralkali vladislav baumgertner to his country for talk on aug. 26 and then arrest him at the airport
uralkali 's chairman aleksandr voloshin and a part owner suleyman kerimov have also be invite but only mr. baumgertner show up
it be unclear whether the others stay clear of belarus because they have sense a trap or whether their schedule simply do not have room for the country 's prime minister which be the formal explanation both official offer
mr. baumgertner be charge with abuse of power which carry a potential 10-year sentence
belarus state television show his glum perp walk past the water stain concrete wall of a prison nickname the american girl lead by a chubby guard in a camouflage uniform
belaruskali which be state own have no public relation office
the switchboard refer call to anatoly v. makhlai whose title be deputy director for ideology and cadre who decline to comment
later the belarussian authorities issue arrest warrant for four other executive and mr. kerimov the part owner
analyst say mr. baumgertner be not likely to serve hard time but be instead be hold as a hostage to compel the russians to rejoin the cartel
outraged the russians respond with a flurry of trade restriction ban all belarussian pork import ostensibly over newly discover health concern
it look like the conflict be escalate boris krasnojenov a mining analyst at renaissance capital an investment bank base in moscow confirm in an interview
farmer and fertilizer company be watch closely
share in the potash corporation of saskatchewan rise earlier this week after sign of a reconciliation
report indicate mr. kerimov would sell his stake to another russian oligarch more palatable to president lukashenko or to the nickel mining company norilsk lead to a patch up of tie and re creation of the price fix cartel
but norilsk say on wednesday that it have no plan to buy a stake
share in potash corporation fall again

this move be absolutely aggressive and abnormal mr. krasnojenov say refer to the arrest of mr. baumgertner
the prime minister invite the c.e.o. of a major company to a meeting and then arrest him

kafkaesque be not a word normally use to describe immune response but it ' how dr. louis j. picker describe what his experimental vaccine do to his rhesus monkey it ' like their t cell be turn into the east german secret police hunt down infected cell until there be none leave
recent work by dr. picker a vaccine expert at oregon health science university have shake up the long frustrating search for an aids vaccine
his late study publish in nature last week have scientist scratch their head wonder if it may open up a new avenue for research
dr. picker test his vaccine in 16 monkey who be then infect with simian immunodeficiency virus a close relative of h.i.v. which normally would have send them spiral rapidly down to a miserable death
the experimental vaccine protect only nine of them but it also do something never see before these monkey slowly clear the virus and now appear to be cure
three year later you can not tell them from other monkey dr. picker say
dr. anthony s. fauci the head of the national institute for allergy and infectious diseases say the effect be unique
and dr. barton f. haynes the director of the human vaccine institute at duke university 's medical school say it be potentially extremely important to understand how this happen
scientist often test idea for potential aids vaccine by create similar one against s.i.v. never before have one eliminate an exist infection
in that sense the effect of dr. picker 's vaccine be less like that of a measles or flu shot and more like that of the aids cure use in two famous case know as the berlin patient and the mississippi baby
the berlin patient timothy ray brown be infect with h.i.v. and cure only by obliterate his immune system to defeat his leukemia and then inject bone marrow from a donor with a rare h.i.v.-block mutation
the unidentified baby be bear to an infected mother in mississippi and apparently infect with h.i.v. but then cure with early and large dos of antiretroviral drug
both now appear to have no h.i.v. lurk deep in their body but it be impossible to be sure because not every bit of their tissue can be test
because he work with monkey dr. picker be able to do something that would be unthinkable with human patient necropsy them grind up every organ and take 240 sample from each to be sure that they harbor no hidden virus
make vaccine by simply weaken the virus that cause aids have fail because the virus mutate a hundred time faster than even the fast mutate flu virus
in dr. picker 's vaccine s.i.v. gene be fuse to those of another virus the cytomegalovirus
the name mean big cell and it be in the herpes family but different from its relative that cause lip and genital sore chickenpox and shingle
h.i.v. fusion have be try with adenovirus and others but cytomegalovirus seem to work better
it ' not entirely clear why but one theory be that cytomegalovirus have a very long history of infect primate so much so that 100 percent of monkey and about 80 percent of human get it in their lifetime
therefore we primate have adapt to it
although the virus can be lethal to fetus and to those with immune system suppress by aids or transplant drug in most victim it cause no symptom
the body respond to cytomegalovirus more slowly and calmly than it do for example to a flu
as in any infection the thymus gland generate new white blood cell call t cell in this case cd8 hunter killer cell prim to target the specific virus
but in the case of dr. picker 's vaccine those cell stay in an unusual half alert state
a full blown immune response eventually exhaust itself and can even be dangerous
for example the rare human who catch h5n1 bird flu often die of the immune response itself they drown in the flood of cd8s and other would be savior pour into the lung tissue spoil for a fight
that half alert state be the kafkaesque element unactivated cd8s wander around aimlessly while fully activate one behave like storm trooper
but the half activate cd8s persist in tissue eliminate their target quietly without trigger inflammation or even a mild fever
when s.i.v. gene be fuse to the cytomegalovirus spine the cd8s kill s.i.v.-infected cell too
since it protect only some monkey the new technique may be best use in combination approach
for example dr. fauci say it could be give with a vaccine that generate antibody against h.i.v. and maybe eliminate the cell that sneak past the antibody shield
alternatively the vaccine may be give to infected patient who be on antiretroviral drug to see if it can mop up linger reservoir of virus
it should take up to three year to get a human version ready for trial dr. picker estimate
now the outstanding question be why only half?'â say dr. mike mccune an aids researcher at the university of california san francisco refer to the monkey who be protect in dr. picker 's trial
too often aids advance that work in lot of monkey do not work in many human
not all monkey be the same dr. mccune say
they 're not as inbred as mouse but they 're sometimes from the same family they get the same diet
who know what will happen if this go into human

chinese food have be popular since american start go out to dinner but cook it at home have never quite catch on maybe because so many americanize chinese restaurant still serve sweet and sticky or deep fried dish i 'm look at you general tso 's chicken that do not seem like good weeknight choice

gong bao chicken with peanuts adapt from every grain of rice simple chinese home cooking by fuchsia dunlop
w.w. norton company 2013
time 40 minute yield 2 to 3 serving for the chicken 2 boneless chicken breast 11 to 12 ounce total with or without skin 3 garlic clove an equivalent amount of ginger 5 spring onion white part only a handful of dry chile about 10 2 tablespoon cook oil 1 teaspoon whole sichuan pepper 3 ounce 75 gram roasted peanut see note for the marinade 1/2 teaspoon salt 2 teaspoon light soy sauce
1 teaspoon shaoxing wine or use dry sherry or dry vermouth 1 1/2 teaspoon potato starch or cornstarch for the sauce 1 tablespoon sugar 3/4 teaspoon potato starch or cornstarch 1 teaspoon dark soy sauce 1 teaspoon light soy sauce 1 tablespoon chinkiang vinegar or use balsamic vinegar
1 teaspoon sesame oil 1 tablespoon chicken stock or water 1
cut chicken as evenly as possible into half inch strip then cut strip into small cube
place in a small bowl
add marinade ingredient and 1 tablespoon water to bowl
mix well and set aside
2
peel and thinly slice garlic and ginger
chop spring onion into chunk as long as their diameter to match the chicken cube
snip chile in half or into section discard their seed
3
in a small bowl combine the sauce ingredient
4
heat a seasoned wok over a high flame
add oil chile and sichuan pepper and stir fry briefly until chile be darken but not burn
remove wok from heat if necessary to prevent overheating
5
quickly add chicken and stir fry over a high flame stir constantly
as soon as chicken cube have separate add ginger garlic and spring onion and continue to stir fry until they be fragrant and meat be just cook through test one of the large piece to make sure
6
give sauce a stir and add to wok continue to stir and toss
as soon as the sauce have become thick and shiny add the peanut stir them in and serve
note store buy roasted peanut work well here but if you want to roast your own peanut heat oven to 250 degree
place raw nut on an oven tray and roast for 15 to 20 minute until fragrant and very slightly golden
keep an eye on them as they be easily burn
cool nut on a plate then rub nut between your fingertip to loosen their skin
shake nut as you blow over them skin will blow away

in particular the scene transition in which the twin waltz around the stage and blow some sort of fairy dust upon various light fixture feel like force whimsy
touch like this and other strained physical comedy gum up the pacing and blunt the sharp social commentary that mr. staller celebrate in the program note
while this pearl theater company revival may not deliver the sociopolitical punch that shaw intend it be still brighten by some strong performance particularly those of dan daily as a wizened waiter and zachary spicer as his son a smug barrister who have embarrass his servant class father by rise above his social status
it ' be a long time since i have see a play as brutal as carcass
it may be even longer before i can scrub its residue from my mind
severe and unrelentingly grim the piece be often difficult to watch several audience member flinch during its most vicious moment
yet carcass be also tough to look away from especially in this cunning production that intensify every angry scene

it ' no surprise that the program feature a work by egon schiele
as avrush david greenspan 's bile seep into every sentence

thomas preece kathryn rossetter and robyn kerr round out the cast of six none of whom shrink from their character fury
carcass be certainly not for the casual theatergoer
but this rarely perform 70-minute work offer dark reward for those who can stomach its depiction of physical and psychological cruelty
make no mistake the play be never fun
but it ' almost always fascinating

when it come to make money twitter be all about keep it simple
there be no banner ad no dancing animation no ad insert between screen that you must click to get past
virtually all of the company 's revenue which be project to be nearly $ 600 million this year and $ 950 million next year come from three basic advertising format that blend smoothly into its core microblogging service whether user be access it from a mobile phone or a web browser
what they have be able to do very well be develop product that meet the need of most advertiser without be overly complex say debra aho williamson principal analyst for social medium at emarketer a research firm
but the simplicity of twitter 's product be also a weakness especially when compare with other social network like facebook
the company do not have concrete demographic information about individual user like gender and age to allow it to sell highly targeted ad at expensive rate
and its marketing effort have largely be orient toward large advertiser in the united states with few sale to small business and only about one fifth of its ad revenue come from overseas ms. williamson say
twitter which announce last week that it have file confidential paperwork to begin the process of sell stock in an initial public offering have disclose virtually no information about its finance
the company decline to comment for this article cite regulatory restriction surround its i.p.o.
but emarketer estimate that the company will bring in $ 583 million in revenue from advertise this year and $ 950 million in 2014
twitter also make additional revenue from sell the data in its raw feed of hundred of million of message daily
the most common type of twitter ad especially on mobile device be the promote tweet
essentially advertiser create a twitter message limit to 140 character like any other message on the service and pay to insert it into the flow of message that a user see base on certain trait like age gender or keywords that a person be interested in
so if you search for apple iphone on twitter the first message that be likely to appear be a pay ad from google 's motorola unit which be run a campaign proclaim the virtue of its android smartphones love to talk
moto x respond to your voice no touch necessary read one or from microsoft which be push its windows phone device watch how the 41-megapixel windowsphone nokia lumia 1020 make any seat the best seat in the house
both company be bid against each other to reach people interested in the iphone
in many way the result resemble the ad that pop up at the top of the page after a web search on google which also emphasize simplicity in its ad business
as with google twitter 's advertiser set key parameter like target audience and how much they want to spend and then computer program submit bid instantly to serve ad to available slot
advertiser pay only when someone interact with an ad such as by retweeting it to their follower comment on it or mark it as a favorite
that typically happen only 1 to 3 percent of the time
to get that rate on the high side twitter 's system do not just automatically award an ad slot to the high bidder instead it give an advantage to ad that previous viewer have find to be more relevant or engage
the holy grail for advertiser be an ad that be widely share by twitter user to their own follower
to increase the chance of go viral brand will often embed photo and video into their ad
twitter 's other ad format be even simple
the company 's list of trend topic the most popular 10 or so subject be discuss at any give moment on the service be well know as a window into society 's transient obsession
advertiser can pay a flat fee to buy their way onto the list
the price for such a promoted trend which be clearly label vary by country but run about $ 200,000 for 24 hour of exposure to every twitter user in the united states
company or people seek to build follower for their account can also pay to appear on the top of the list of new account to follow that twitter suggest to each user
as twitter prepare to sell stock to the public the company be plan initiative that will add complexity to its advertising business while also diversify its revenue stream
last week for example it announce that it have agree to acquire mopub a start up that act as a middleman in place ad from marketer inside mobile application
mopub do something quite different from twitter auction off two billion ad slot a day in apps like songza and opentable through dozen of ad network and deliver the ad so quickly that a user fire up the app barely notice
but jim payne chief executive of mopub say the two company share a common dna.
like mopub he say twitter be design to be mobile and it be design to be real time
he say twitter have promise to let mopub continue build out its current business even as the two work together to improve the ad offering on twitter itself
ms. williamson the emarketer analyst say mopub could become a significant source of revenue for twitter
mopub 's technology will streamline their self serve platform she say
it give twitter entree into the real time bidding business the ad network business mobile app ad
through its amplify program twitter be also aggressively promote joint ad sale with television channel

young people be different
the supreme court have deliver that message repeatedly over the last decade in limit or flatly prohibit the most severe criminal punishment for those under 18 at the time of their crime
in 2005 the court ban the death penalty for juvenile
in 2010 it outlaw sentence of life without parole for juvenile convict of crime other than homicide
and in a 2012 case miller v. alabama it say juvenile may never receive a mandatory sentence of life without parole which prisoner refer to as the other death penalty
each ruling rely on the eighth amendment 's ban on cruel and unusual punishment have find that young people be constitutionally different from adult and therefore must be punish differently
in each case the court be silent on the question of whether its ruling apply retroactively to inmate who have already be convict
the just answer would surely be yes and court have largely agree make those first two juvenile justice ruling retroactive
but some state insist that the ban on mandatory life without parole do not apply to offender who have already be sentence
in the miller case the court require low court to make individualized sentencing decision for juvenile defendant because juvenile be not as morally culpable as adult and they be more capable of change over time
if the ban on mandatory life without parole be retroactive more than 2,000 prisoner would be eligible for a new sentencing hearing
so far whether these individual can get a new hearing depend on where they live
court in michigan iowa and mississippi have rule that the ban apply to previously sentence juvenile
the department of justice take that position as well
yet the minnesota supreme court and one federal appeal court have take the opposite view
on sept. 4 the louisiana supreme court take on this question in the case of darryl tate who be 17 when he hold up two man and kill one of them in 1981
mr. tate 's lawyer argue that he be entitled to a new sentencing hear under the miller rule because the united states supreme court allow such a rehearing in another juvenile life without parole case decide at the same time as miller
critic fear that allow resentencing would increase violent crime
but court may still impose life without parole provide that the judge first give proper consideration to the mitigating effect of youth
the alabama supreme court set out guideline last week that require a court to consider 14 factor include a defendant 's age emotional maturity family environment and potential for rehabilitation before issue such a sentence
ideally life without parole would never be a sentencing option for juvenile
the supreme court 's own logic suggest this even if it be not willing to go that far
after the miller case three state entirely eliminate juvenile life without parole join six other state that have already ban the sentence and lawsuit on the retroactivity issue be pending in several state

drill for shale ga through hydraulic fracturing or fracking appear to cause small leak of the greenhouse ga methane than the federal government have estimate and considerably small than some critic of shale ga have fear accord to a peer review study release on monday
the study conduct by the university of texas and sponsor by the environmental defense fund and nine petroleum company bolster the contention by advocate of fracking and some environmental group as well that shale ga be clean and better than coal at least until more renewable energy source be develop
more than 500 well be analyze
the texas study conclude that while the total amount of escape methane from shale ga operation be substantial more than one million ton annually it be probably less than the environmental protection agency estimate in 2011
in particular it indicate that containment measure capture 99 percent of methane that escape from new well be prepare for production a process know as completion
the environmental protection agency have begin to require drillers to control leak during completion which be believe to be one of the major source of methane loss at fracking well
although control will not be require until january 2015 a number of company already capture escaped gas at well be prepare for production
can we control it
thanks to new e.p.a. regulation come online the answer to that be good news eric pooley a senior vice president at the environmental defense fund say in an interview
the report be publish monday in the proceeding of the national academy of sciences
with the study which run from may through december of last year the university be the first to conduct detailed examination of individual drilling site
it do so with the consent of petroleum company which provide about 90 percent of the financing for the study
previous e.p.a. estimate rely on engineering calculation and other study gather data via aircraft flight over drilling site
the study 's connection to the petroleum industry among its sponsor and financier be shell anadarko petroleum corporation exxon mobil and chevron may lead some to question its objectivity some outside expert say
but most say the research and the reputation of the researcher appear solid
previous study that have get a lot of attention have have red flag jump out all over them
this one do n't say michael a. levi the director of the program on energy security and climate change at the council on foreign relations
in an e mail statement shell 's president marvin odum call the study a prime example of key group that may not have the exact same interest work collaboratively and take a science base approach to the methane problem
mr. odum say that collect actual emission data rather than rely on estimate would ensure that both improvement effort and regulatory change can be focus on the area that will have the big impact
the report come at a time when shale ga drilling be grow at a breakneck pace production now 30 percent of all united states natural ga be expect to reach 50 percent by 2040 but also when the industry be beset by controversy
citizen group accuse drillers of despoil stream and water supply and supplier of wreck local road with parade of massive truck

the texas study be the most comprehensive look to date at a contentious issue in the debate over fracking the extent to which methane leak during drilling and production offset the environmental benefit of the clean burn natural ga the well produce
when burn as fuel methane the main component of natural ga be comparatively clean produce less carbon dioxide than coal and oil
but vent to the air it be a short live but extremely potent greenhouse ga trap heat at a much high rate than carbon dioxide the main greenhouse ga
such potency mean that even a small loss of methane to the air just 3.4 percent scientist say can negate its climate change advantage over coal
some previous study suggest that as much as 7.9 percent of all shale ga be lose to the atmosphere a figure that include every stage of the ga process from well to stove or furnace burner
the texas study do not examine potential loss outside the drilling pad
but its conclusion that loss at the well be comparatively low could remove one issue from the debate
the environmental defense fund be lead other research effort that should address loss elsewhere include a look at methane leak in municipal ga distribution line
the american petroleum institute hail the study 's conclusion say in a statement that its own effort to reduce methane emission be pay off
but while e.p.a.-mandated measure appear to have reduce emission during well completion the study also conclude that leak elsewhere in the fracking process be high than the e.p.a. have previously estimate
estimate of leak from chemical pump while small be twice past estimate while leak from pneumatic controller or valve be peg at more than 639,000 ton a year roughly a third great
none of those component be currently subject to federal regulation

in the future more robot will occupy that strange gray zone do not only job that human can do but also job that require social grace
in the last decade an interdisciplinary field of research call human robot interaction have arise to study the factor that make robot work well with human and how human view their robotic counterpart
h.r.i. researcher have discover some rather surprising thing a robot 's behavior can have a big impact on its relationship with human than its design many of the rule that govern human relationship apply equally well to human robot relation and people will read emotion and motivation into a robot 's behavior that far exceed the robot 's capability
as we employ those lesson to build robot that can be better caretaker maid and emergency responder we risk further blur the once unnecessary line between tool and being
provide with the right behavioral cue human will form relationship with just about anything regardless of what it look like
even a stick can trigger our social promiscuity
in 2011 ehud sharlin a computer scientist at the university of calgary run an observational experiment to test this impulse to connect
his subject sit alone in a room with a very simple robot a long balsa wood rectangle attach to some gear control by a joystick wield human who hide from view run it through a series of predetermined movement

some try to dance with it

they describe the stick as bow in greeting search for hide item even purr like a contented cat
when a robot move on its own it exploit a fundamental social instinct that all human have the ability to separate thing into object like rock and tree and agent like a bug or another person
its evolutionary importance seem self evident typically kid can do this by the time they 're a year old
the distinction run deep than know something be capable of movement
nobody question the motivation of a rock roll down a hill say brian scassellati director of yale 's social robotics lab
agent on the other hand have internal state that we speculate about
the ability to distinguish between agent and object be the basis for another important human skill that scientist call cognitive empathy or theory of mind depend on whom you ask the ability to predict what other being be think and what they want by watch how they move
we make these assumption very quickly and naturally scassellati say
and it ' not new or even limit to the world of robotics
look at animation
they know the rule too
a sack of flour can look sad or angry
it ' all about how it move

it ' not worth try to persuade anyone to become vegan for a couple of very good reason one it ' a losing battle and two it ' far from certain that a diet with no animal product be best for everyone
it ' increasingly evident however that a part time vegan diet one that emphasize minimally processed plant food at the expense of everything else be the direction that will do the most to benefit human health increase animal welfare and reduce environmental impact
the remain challenge an undeniably big one be to figure out how to make such a diet which you may also call flexitarian the standard
my own diet which i call vegan

take advantage in a few month there may be little more than root vegetable apple cider and hand dye yarn
when fruit and vegetable be at their best they give you insight into how the vegan thing can work for you if only for a day
and give a moderate degree of freshness most conventional vegetable from ordinary supermarket can be make to taste good when garden go dormant

credibility be a prized word in international politics
country that keep their promise and enforce their red line can be count on to deter their enemy and assure their allies
nation as with human being develop reputation and those that break their pledge be impossible to trust
as such the failure of the united states to bomb syria be bind to empower iran and reinforce its quest for nuclear arm

it be washington 's allies however that be likely to prove sensitive to its intention as oppose to its actual power
the event of the past few week have probably impact israel more so than iran

tokyo eiji toyoda who as a member of toyota motor 's found family and an architect of its lean manufacturing method help turn the automaker into a global powerhouse and change the face of modern manufacturing die on tuesday in toyota city japan where the company have its headquarters
he be 100
his death at the toyota memorial hospital be cause by heart failure the company say in a statement
mr. toyoda a nephew of the toyota group founder sakichi toyoda be president of toyota from 1967 to 1982 and continue as chairman and then as adviser until his death
in almost six decade with the company he help transform a tiny spinoff of a textile loom maker into the world 's big automaker
early on he help put toyota at the forefront of a wave of automobile production in japan push it to bolster its lineup first by add compact vehicle and sport car in the 1960 and 1970
in the 1980 he initiate the development of luxury model to compete with the like of mercedes benz and bmw culminate with the lexus brand in 1989
mr. toyoda also push toyota 's expansion overseas help to establish the company 's joint factory with general motors in fremont calif.
the plant know as nummi introduce japanese lean production method to the united states as part of a migration of japanese auto manufacturing to american soil
the company 's manufacturing efficiency have help maintain toyota 's status as one of the top auto manufacturer and employer in the world
nummi close in 2010
it be now the site of a factory that make the electric car trailblazer tesla
in the early 1990 mr. toyoda know as a man of few word give voice to a sense of crisis inside the company as japan 's economic growth sputter
he argue that toyota need to change the way it make car if it hop to survive in the 21st century
his urging prompt the development of the popular prius ga electric hybrid the manufacturing expert satoshi hino write in the 2005 book inside the mind of toyota
mr. toyoda be bear on sept. 12 1913 near nagoya in central japan the second son of heikichi and nao toyoda
he spend much of his youth at his family 's textile mill and take an early interest in machine he say in his 1988 autobiography toyota fifty year in motion
he graduate from the university of tokyo in 1936 with a mechanical engineering degree and join his family 's loom business
the next year kiichiro toyoda son of the founder create toyota motor take the young eiji toyoda with him
assign to a division devote to resolve quality problem mr. toyoda be say to have develop an uncanny ability to spot waste
problem be roll all around in front of your eye mr. toyoda say of those day in inside the mind of toyota
whether you pick them up and treat them as problem be a matter of habit
if you have the habit then you can do whatever you have a mind to
in 1950 he set out on what would turn out to be a pivotal three month tour to survey ford 's rouge plant in detroit then the large and most efficient factory in the world
before world war ii the military government prevent toyota from build passenger car compel it to make truck for japan 's war effort instead
by 1950 toyota have produce just 2,685 automobile compare with the 7,000 vehicle the rouge plant be roll out in a single day accord to the machine that change the world a 1990 study by james p. womack daniel t. jones and daniel roos
mr. toyoda be unfazed write back to headquarters that he think there be some possibility to improve the production system
he bring back a thick booklet that outline some of ford 's quality control method the company translate it into japanese change ford to toyota in all reference
mr. toyoda go on to oversee toyota 's motomachi plant a huge undertaking that give the automaker the capacity to produce 5,000 passenger vehicle a month at a time when all of japan produce about 7,000 vehicle a month
the plant complete in 1959 be soon run at full capacity and give toyota a decisive lead over its domestic rival nissan and the confidence to turn its eye overseas
even as he aggressively expand production at toyota mr. toyoda apply a manufacturing culture base on concept like kaizen a commitment to continuous improvement suggest by the worker themselves and just in time production a tireless effort to eliminate waste
those idea become a core part of what come to be call the toyota production system and a corporate ethos know as the toyota way
one of the feature of the japanese worker be that they use their brain as well as their hand he say in an interview with the author masaaki imai for the 1986 book kaizen
our worker provide 1.5 million suggestion a year and 95 percent of them be put to practical use
there be an almost tangible concern for improvement in the air at toyota
the method mr. toyoda nurture have have global influence

not only do this introduce us to the woman whose dictate dominate the succeed opera but the issue of elizabeth 's illegitimate birth be bring to the fore

sadly mr. frey 's staging fall short of do that opera justice

you can also set light metering to measure the center of the picture the whole scene or a small spot in the middle just as you would on serious digital single lens reflex camera
and you can even set white balance for daylight cloudy condition fluorescent or tungsten light
you can also adjust exposure and the camera have a rudimentary filter menu which can make your photo color black and white sepia or negative or even in tint of red green or blue
that leave a lot of room for creativity but it would be a mistake to call the camera sophisticated
it essentially have a pinhole lens fix focus and a very slow shutter speed
that mean that lot of your photo be go to be a little soft although it do have a screw mount for a tripod to help steady the camera
the color be quite muted
and you get a natural vignette effect a kind of darken around the edge that draw your eye to the center
but it be those limitation that can make the image compel
offer in red black blue white and pink the camera be available online for $ 40
but you will also need a microsd memory card which be not include
a 2gb card can be find online for less than $ 10

the obama administration announce on tuesday that it be extend minimum wage and overtime protection to the nation 's nearly two million home care worker
advocate for low wage worker have push for this change assert that home care worker who care for elderly and disabled americans be wrongly classify into the same companionship service category as baby sitter a group that be exempt from minimum wage and overtime coverage
under the new rule home care aide unlike baby sitter would be cover under the fair labor standards act the nation 's main wage and hour law
in an unusual move the administration say the new regulation would not take effect until jan. 1 2015 even though regulation often take effect 60 day after be issue
the delay until 2015 be to give family that use these attendant as well as state medicaid program time to prepare
industry expert say most of these worker be already pay at least the minimum wage but many do not receive a time and a half overtime premium when they work more than 40 hour a week
about 20 state exclude home care worker from their wage and hour law

we 've see a lot of turnover in this industry and we believe that this new rule will stabilize the work force
the nation 's home care worker usually earn $ 8.50 to $ 12 an hour accord to industry official
the federal minimum wage be $ 7.25 an hour
accord to the obama administration almost 40 percent of aide receive government benefit like food stamp and medicaid
ninety two percent of these worker be female almost 30 percent be black and 12 percent be hispanic

but industry official say the change would cause increase in medicaid and medicare spending raise cost for family that use such service and result in few job for home care worker
andrea l. devoti chairman of the national association for home care and hospice say the new rule will mean that people will receive less care

the newly issue rule be also criticize by representative john kline a minnesota republican who be chairman of the house education and the work force committee and representative tim walberg a michigan republican who head the panel 's subcommittee on work force protection

many labor advocate criticize the administration for take so long to issue its final rule but labor department official say review the comment and hold related public meeting take time

the exemption for aide who mainly provide companionship service define as fellowship and protection for an elderly person or person with an illness injury or disability who require assistance be limit to the individual family or household use the service
if an aide or companion provide care that exceed 20 percent of the total hour she work each week then the worker be to receive minimum wage and overtime protection
the new rule define care as assist with the activity of daily living like dress groom feed or bathing and assist with instrumental activity of daily living like meal preparation drive light housework manage finance and assist with the physical taking of medication
the companionship exemption will not apply if the aide or companion provide medically relate service that be typically perform by train personnel like nurse or certify nursing assistant

the effect enrich your listening experience make your music sound full and deep

the restaurant takeaway column be devote to restaurant dish you can make in your own kitchen test and tweak for home cook
there ' the usual eggplant parmesan sandwich and then there ' frankies spuntino 's fried eggplant sandwich
and for all the similarity of content and form the two be league apart
that ' because the version at frankies spuntino so name for owner frank falcinelli and frank castronovo be base on their grandmother recipe bring over from italy
it be a sandwich that ' crisp and tender lightly oily in a good way and fill with salty pungent flavor from a combination of pecorino cheese and parmigiano reggiano that add intensity without the gloppy factor of melt mozzarella
the secret be in its technique
the eggplant be cook three time to render it as tender as silk offer absolutely no resistance to the tooth and top with sweet garlicky tomato sauce
then airy crusty ciabatta be toast until quite crisp
this give a textural contrast and keep the whole sandwich firmly together though if you 're not careful the sauce will drip down your chin and possibly all over your shirt keep a napkin close by
give that the recipe involve a double frying and then baking it ' not a sandwich to make on a whim
but if you plan ahead you will be in for a feast make the eggplant up to five day ahead and reheat just before serve
after all how can you doubt not one but two italian grandmother
frankies spuntino 's fried eggplant sandwich
time 3 hour 20 minute yield 6 serving 1 1/2 cup extra virgin olive oil 6 garlic clove peel pinch red chile flake 2 28-ounce can whole peel tomato 1 teaspoon coarse kosher salt more as need 5 small italian eggplant 2 pound 4 large egg 6 tablespoon grind parmigiano reggiano more as need 6 tablespoon ground pecorino romano more as need 1 very large or 2 medium ciabatta loaf for serve 1
in a large deep saucepan over medium low heat combine 1/4 cup oil and garlic
cook stir occasionally until garlic be golden and fragrant 5 to 10 minute
stir in chile flake cook 30 second
2
while garlic cook place tomato and juice in a large bowl and crush with clean hand
remove tomato firm stem end and any basil leaf pack into the can
stir crush tomato and salt into pot
simmer over medium heat stir frequently until tomato and garlic have completely break down and sauce be thick about 2 hour
cool
3 line a large rimmed baking sheet with parchment or paper towel
trim stem end from eggplant peel and discard skin
use a knife or a japanese mandolin slice lengthwise into 3/16-inch thick slab
arrange eggplant in a single layer on prepared baking sheet
sprinkle both side of eggplant slice with salt
let stand 10 minute
pat eggplant dry with paper towel
4 line another rimmed baking sheet with paper towel and place a wire rack on top
in a large deep skillet heat 1/2 cup oil until a drop of water flick into pan sizzle
work in batch fry eggplant until just tender 20 to 30 second per side
transfer fry eggplant to rack to drain
remove skillet from heat
5
in a large bowl whisk together egg 2 tablespoon parmigiano reggiano and 2 tablespoon pecorino
add 3/4 cup oil to the skillet and return to medium high heat until oil be sizzle
6
work in batch dip drain eggplant into egg batter fry in oil until lightly golden and cook through 2 to 4 minute per batch
you will know oil be hot enough if batter puff and stick to eggplant on contact with oil
if it fall off the oil be not hot enough
7
heat oven to 350 degree
spread 1/2 cup tomato sauce in the bottom of a 9-inch square bake pan
arrange eggplant over the bottom of pan in a tight even layer
top with 1/3 of the remain combine cheese
repeat layer of sauce eggplant and 1/3 of cheese
finish with a final layer of sauce and cheese reserve any remain sauce for serve
transfer pan to oven and bake until cheese be melt and golden 20 to 30 minute
remove from oven spoon additional sauce over top and garnish with additional cheese
cool for at least 20 minute
8
cut eggplant into six equal piece
cut ciabatta into six piece equal to the size of the eggplant serving
split each portion of the ciabatta horizontally and toast
sandwich eggplant portion between bread and serve

the saxophone be the most ambiguous of instrument

khartoum sudan on the corner of an old colonial building in downtown khartoum sit the city 's old bookstore sudan bookshop
it be establish in 1902 three year after britain establish control over sudan and for a long time it be a magnet for the city 's civil servant politician and intellectual
today however it be a ghost of itself
it be dusty cold and empty of buyer and it display book publish mostly in the 70 and 80
sudan bookshop 's manager el tayeb abdel rahman 69 still come to work every morning at 8:30
dress in a chic suit and tie he await customer who rarely come

but now no one read anymore
these be hard time for bookstore everywhere of course
and as in other book love corner sudanese be quick to lament that technology and the internet have be turn eye away from page and toward screen
but there be more at work here in a city long famous as a big market for arabic writer
book and reading be embed profoundly in khartoum 's self image and the country 's history and there be grow worry that the collapse of book culture be a direct mirror of the country 's overall decline
most sudanese be more concerned with bread than book and for good reason
year of war drought and economic privation have leave deep mark
a once prestigious education system have crumble and the number of bookstore in khartoum have fall with it
that sense of urgency and loss be drive a new wave of activism with its sight on revive khartoum 's reputation as a literary city
we want to bring people back to book say abdullah al zain 58 who start a project with friend call mafroush a sudanese arabic word mean display

others arrive with more book for the display
you see we do not like to call them use book rather rebated,'â
mr. al zain say
al mutasim hassan 25 a graduate student come search for philosophy book
i think mafroush be a creative endeavor and you meet other reader he say
mr. hassan hold himself apart from others in his generation who think facebook and chat be the only expression of progress he say
i find myself however that when i read a book i feel alive he add
for many who be try to revive reading here the internet be turn into an ally
the internet be not necessarily an enemy of book mr. al zain say
it be so only for those who want it to be such
we use the internet to promote our program
across town in khartoum 's green square another group be also try to encourage sudanese to return to book
hundred of sudanese youth meet in the square on another afternoon each with a book in hand

any public official convict of federal corruption charge could lose their government pension under new policy announce on tuesday night by the top federal prosecutor in manhattan
the policy aim at end the longstanding practice of jail politician continue to collect public money be detail by preet bharara the united states attorney for the southern district of new york at the first public hearing of the moreland commission to investigate public corruption
the 25-member panel be establish in july by gov. andrew m. cuomo to address what have be widely decry as a corruption crisis in albany and other political sphere in new york state
mr. bharara say that as part of the initiative prosecutor in his office file court paper on monday in two separate corruption case give notice that they be add the pension of two state senator a city councilman and two other official to the list of property subject to forfeiture if the official be convict
any forfeiture action against a convict official 's pension would require judicial approval
mr. bharara call it a galling injustice that corrupt official can draw a publicly fund pension until their die day
he say that the statute under which official for decade have be able to collect their pension despite corruption conviction be an error of state law and he note that while it have be partially fix several year ago it must succumb to common sense
convict politician should not grow old comfortably cushion by a pension pay for by the very people they betray in office he say
more than 30 new york state politician have be indict or convict of a crime censure or otherwise accuse of misconduct in the last seven year
the official whose pension could become subject to forfeiture as a result of the new filing be state senator malcolm a. smith state senator eric stevenson city councilman daniel j. halloran and noramie jasmin and joseph desmaret the mayor and deputy mayor of the rockland county town of spring valley
senator smith a democrat and councilman halloran a republican both from queens be charge on april 2 with plot to bribe republican party boss to place the senator on the ballot in the city 's mayoral race
the two spring valley official be charge in the same case in a separate real estate scheme
mr. stevenson be charge two day later in an unrelated case accuse of take more than $ 22,000 in bribe to help developer open adult day care center in his bronx district
mr. smith 's lawyer gerald l. shargel say the action by prosecutor be premature
they can not have forfeiture without a conviction and what i be focus on be defend the allegation in the indictment and i be eager to do that he say
vinoo p. varghese a lawyer for councilman halloran contend that it be inappropriate for mr. bharara to speak about his client before the public commission because he say the councilman have not commit a crime
lawyer for mr. stevenson and ms. jasmin decline to comment and mr. desmaret 's lawyer do not respond to e mail and voice mail message
mr. bharara say that under his office 's new policy prosecutor would also seek what he call appropriate fine with an eye toward the money that convict corrupt official may receive from publicly finance pension so the punishment fit the crime and so we can take the profit out of that crime
he also say that his office would consider civil forfeiture action against the pension of corrupt official who be previously convict and who fail to pay fine forfeiture or restitution impose at sentencing in order to satisfy those criminal judgment
and in future case as well as pending one like those in which action be take on monday prosecutor will use federal forfeiture law to strip politician convict of corruption charge
the panel convene at pace university also hear testimony from loretta e. lynch the united states attorney in brooklyn and cyrus r. vance jr. the manhattan district attorney
ms. lynch outline some of the current allegation face legislator include filing false travel voucher and more serious crime like obstruction of justice while mr. vance call for toughen state corruption law which he say be weak that those that prohibit thing like fix a fight
those that bribe public official in new york be less likely to be prosecute than those that bribe boxer mr. vance say
outside protester gather to rally for strong corruption law chant follow the money amid a heavy police and security presence
but the establishment of the corruption commission have be meet with a lukewarm response in the legislature which fail to pass a comprehensive corruption and campaign bill earlier this year
william j. fitzpatrick the district attorney in onondaga county and the commission 's co chairman make a veiled reference to that in opening remark to the panel which include nine other district attorney from around the state law professor and lawyer at major private firm
you may think that if you run a business where 35 of your employee in a five year period be indict convict or investigate and lead out in handcuff that this may inspire a period of reflection mr. fitzgerald say
