washington the foreign intelligence surveillance court on tuesday offer its most extensive public explanation for why it have allow the government to keep record of all americans phone call release a previously classify opinion in which it say the program be constitutional and do not violate americans privacy right
while the once secret call log program have be periodically reapproved by the court since 2006 it have come under criticism from member of congress of both party and civil libertarian since its existence come to public light in june after leak by the former national security agency contractor edward j. snowden
in a 29-page opinion that quote the n.s.a. director keith alexander as say the leak have cause significant and irreversible damage to national security judge claire v. eagan a federal judge in the northern district of oklahoma declare that the program be lawful
so she write any decision about whether to keep it be a political question not a legal one
this court be mindful that this matter come before it at a time when unprecedented disclosure have be make about this and other highly sensitive program design to obtain foreign intelligence information and carry out counterterrorism investigation she write add in the wake of these disclosure whether and to what extent the government seek to continue the program discuss in this memorandum opinion be a matter for the political branch to decide
the opinion by judge eagan a 2001 appointee of president george w. bush who be assign to the surveillance court by chief justice john g. roberts jr. this year also note that no telecommunication company have invoke its legal right to object to turn over its customer call record to the government
to date no holder of record who have receive an order to produce bulk telephony metadata have challenge the legality of such an order she write
the opinion date aug. 29 be the first write since the program come to light
while other judge have routinely reauthorized the program every 90 day with only brief reiteration of the court 's legal analysis accord to an official familiar with the still classified ruling judge eagan write the lengthy memorandum apparently for the purpose of public release
judge eagan note in her opinion that the court have previously reauthorized the program to continue for another three month on july 19 after have hold an extensive hearing to receive testimony and evidence on this matter

in a footnote she say that only the government and not opponent of the program participate in the hearing as be routine for such proceeding
james r. clapper the director of national intelligence laud the opinion as one that affirm that the bulk telephony metadata collection be both lawful and constitutional
in a statement he say its release be consistent with president obama 's call for more transparency on these valuable intelligence program
but jameel jaffer a senior attorney at the american civil liberties union call the opinion completely unpersuasive criticize it for fail to mention a landmark privacy case decide by the supreme court last year and portray its statutory analysis as equally weak
on the whole the opinion only confirm the folly of entrust privacy right to a court that hear argument only from the government he say
the legal analysis judge eagan endorse echo the basic argument that the obama administration have make in defend the program since it come to light include in an unsigned justice department white paper it release last month
among those argument be that phone call metadata phone number time and duration of call but not content be not protect by fourth amendment privacy right because it do not involve eavesdropping on the content of call
she also agree that the government have legal authority to collect all calling record from phone company under a provision of the patriot act that allow it to obtain business record deem relevant to an investigation and that member of congress have have an opportunity to learn how the patriot act be secretly be interpret before lawmaker reauthorized the law
the program trace its origin to one aspect of the bush administration 's expansion of surveillance outside statutory or judicial framework after the terrorist attack of sept. 11 2001
it be later bring under the authority of the surveillance court and link to the patriot act
the security agency use the database to perform link analysis see who may have be in contact directly or indirectly with terrorism suspect in hope of identify hidden cell
under rule impose by the court the agency may search for phone call only if there be reasonable articulable suspicion that the underlie phone number be link to terrorism
in explain why the court have reauthorized the program judge eagan say that accord to the government there be no compliance incident violation of the rule limit how the database may be access by analyst in the previous three month period
last week the government release document by another judge on the foreign intelligence surveillance court relate to a 2009 reprimand of the security agency for violate the rule and for mislead the court about how it be use the database
it have come to light that the agency be automatically compare each day 's fresh batch of phone data with an alert list of thousand of number its analyst have flag only about 10 percent of which meet the standard of the court impose rule
the court be aware that in prior year there have be incident of noncompliance with respect to n.s.a. 's handling of produce information judge eagan write
through oversight by this court over a period of month those issue be resolve
the census bureau report yesterday that the poverty rate in america hold stable between 2011 and 2012 at about 15 percent
accord to the official measure poverty today be high than it be in 1973 when it reach a historical low of 11.1 percent
to many this dismaying fact suggest that taxpayer waste billion of dollar a year fight a war on poverty that have be largely lose
as representative paul d. ryan republican of wisconsin say earlier this year we have spend $ 15 trillion from the federal government fight poverty and look at where we be the high poverty rate in a generation 15 percent of americans in poverty
but this position be wrong for two reason
the first be that the official measure be misleading it measure only cash income and it do not count benefit from many program that help the poor
if they be count the rate would be close to 11 percent
consider the supplemental nutrition assistance program commonly know as food stamp which be first put into nationwide use in the 1960
the immediate benefit be easy to calculate a dollar of snap subsidy spend on food free up a dollar for low income family to spend on rent utility or other need
when snap benefit be count as income they lift almost four million people above the poverty line
and snap benefit not only reduce food insecurity and poverty this year they also reduce poverty in the next generation
recent research that track child into adulthood find that family access to food stamp improve their infant health and birth weight
child who benefit from the program later post better health high educational attainment less heart disease and for woman great earnings and less reliance on welfare as adult
the earn income tax credit be also ignore in calculate the poverty rate
yet this program offer work low income family with child about $ 3,000 a year
when these tax refund be count they reduce the number of people in poverty by about 5.5 million people
social security benefit be count in the official measure but their large antipoverty effect receive little attention
without these benefit the elderly poverty rate would have be more than 44 percent instead of the actual rate of less than 9 percent
the next time critic of the safety net claim that we fight a war on poverty and poverty win remind them that without these and other program poverty would be much high
but say the critic if all these program have such broad effect why have the poverty rate stay so frustratingly stable
that ' the second flaw in the conventional wisdom
all thing be equal such program whether we count them or not should have reduce the official poverty rate across generation
but all thing have not be equal
although these program help the poor poverty remain high because inequality of economic outcome have increase sharply since the 1970
before income inequality take off the poverty rate fall more rapidly with g.d.p. growth
but while the economy grow by 2.8 percent in 2012 and corporate profit go up as a share of national income the earnings of full time worker median household income and the poverty rate barely change
antipoverty program do help but their recipient do not move forward because they no longer benefit much from that other great poverty ameliorating factor economic growth
that ' not to say that growth be no longer necessary for reduce poverty
but in our gilded age of inequality growth alone be insufficient
a few change would make a difference
first a poverty measure that incorporate all anti poverty policy would show that the safety net be more effective than critic say and would show how painful cut to those program could be
in fact the census bureau have already develop a supplemental measure that reveal the importance of these program to low income family
but when it be release next month it will receive far less attention than the official rate from policy maker and the press
second more benefit from growth must reach the poor and the best way to do that be through match robust antipoverty measure with policy that lower the unemployment rate and increase wage
during the full employment year of the late 1990 even low wage rise in step with productivity and poverty fall more sharply than it have in a generation
a minimum wage increase help then and an increase now would help again
lower poverty mean both recognize the success of safety net program we now have and devise new policy that can spread the gain generate by economic growth
if we do n't then we will continue to face poverty rate that be unacceptably high and wonder why we can not do anything about them
sheldon h. danziger be the president of the russell sage foundation and a co editor of legacies of the war on poverty

but his be gray now not pink
that ' also the tax you pay for think about the middle east too much it lead to either gray hair or no hair but not pink hair
well bring on the grecian formula because our leader will need it
my big take away from the whole syria imbroglio be that with europe ail china awol and the arab world convulse for an american president to continue to lead will require more help from vladimir putin because our president will get less help from everyone else include the american people
everyone be focus on obama 's unimpressive leadership in this crisis but for my money the two main player who shape the outcome in way that would not have be predict but will have huge long term implication be putin and the american people
obama get blindside by both
what do it tell us
the fact that americans overwhelmingly tell congress to vote against bomb syria for its use of poison ga tell how much the divide on this issue in america be not leave versus right but top versus bottom
intervene in syria be drive by elite and debate by elite

lelystad netherlands on an open plain in front of us be hundred of horse
most of them be gray with black mane and tail
their head look more like those of their wild cousin zebra than those of rid horse
some even show what may be a vestigial stripe on their flank
we could be in the serengeti say hans breeveld my guide refer to the plain in tanzania that be a haven to wildlife
well we almost could
to the north we encounter another big group of large animal this time red deer do with their young
they gaze at us and bleat like sheep
off in the distance be massive cattle with impose horizontal horn that look like they may have walk out of a cave painting
every now and then a brown harrier a large and rare raptor float by and we glimpse a white tail eagle another specie unusual in most of europe perch on a dead tree
rather than africa we be in the netherlands one of the most densely populate country in europe at a place call the oostvaardersplassen
this stretch of swamp and grassland of more than 6,000 hectare or about 15,000 acre be just a 45-minute train ride from amsterdam
and it be the site of a remarkable and controversial experiment that have be the subject of intense national debate and have grab the attention of expert in international wildlife management and animal welfare
this wild area start as low lie polder land that be reclaim from the sea in the late 1960
mr. breeveld who have work as a ranger in the oostvaardersplassen for about 30 year explain that the idea be to put light industry here but the recession hit and investor do not come
in the meantime a small group of scientist and bird watcher notice that the marshy area be attract specie like egret that have become rare or have vanish from the netherlands
something special be transpiring
this give a window into what large part of the netherlands look like in the past say frans vera an ecologist who have be an advocate for the reserve
mr. vera and his allies push for an unusual form of management which as much as possible allow nature to take its course
a bold and persuasive thinker mr. vera argue that the grassy area should be crop not by domestic sheep and cattle but by beast resemble their wild ancestor
as these specie be extinct he settle on konik horse polish descendant of the tarpan and heck cattle which have be breed in germany in an attempt to recreate the aurochs
small group of these animal as well as red deer be introduce in the 1980 and 1990
by three year ago their number have soar to a total of about 4,000 with deer by far the most numerous
in the last couple of year there have be a decline with about 2,700 animal count in april before the breeding season
as in the serengeti or any other natural ecosytem a large proportion of the animal die each year
but the death at oostvaardersplassen mostly because of starvation when food run out in the winter have turn out to be enormously controversial in the netherlands
the preserve become a subject of intense political debate in the news medium and government in the harsh winter earlier this century
while access to theâ oostvaardersplassen be restrict train run frequently along the perimeter of the area give passenger a view of dead animal or whatever else be transpire
a lot of people be visually confront with die animal in the winter say frauke ohl a professor of animal welfare at utrecht university
it be an unusual thing that people can see these thing happen
critic include animal welfare advocate and hunt group argue that to allow animal that be fence in albeit in a large enclosure to starve be cruel and immoral and that the number need to be proactively reduce
hundred of horse cattle and deer die each year from famine say maarten frankenhuis a veterinarian and a former director of the artis zoo in amsterdam
this project be our national shame

one architect interview by the new york times say the light rectilinear effect of this house suggest the simple elegance of line of japanese house
the eminent architect wallace k. harrison buy the house 22 foot and 6 inch by 28 foot and 8 inch and move it to huntington n.y. where he alter and expand it
six year after mr. harrison 's death in 1981 a new owner plan to demolish the house

it be now in storage

in the most significant sign yet of a broad shift in the focus of alzheimer 's research from treat to prevent the disease the federal government announce on wednesday its large grant so far to test an alzheimer 's drug on healthy people at great risk for the most common form of the disease
the $ 33.2 million grant and several other prevention study award federal money in the last year follow year of unsuccessful trial of treatment on people who already have dementia
those failure have lead to the realization that these drug appear to be ineffective by the time memory and thinking problem have take hold
at the same time scientific advance have allow researcher to identify people at risk for alzheimer 's long before symptom emerge
with five million americans suffer from alzheimer 's and their rank project to surge as baby boomer age federal health official consider the disease such a priority that dr. francis s. collins director of the national institutes of health scrap money together when force budget cut slash the obama administration 's promise of $ 100 million in additional funding for alzheimer 's for 2013
dr. collins say he dip into the budget of the 27 n.i.h. agency to supply $ 40 million award wednesday for several alzheimer 's research project
another $ 5 million be provide by the national institute on aging
the bad thing we could do would be to just hunker down and hold off tackle very important problem dr. collins say add obviously this be high risk research but goodness the stake be so high that we feel we have to go forward even in the face of the most difficult budget environment that anyone can remember in the n.i.h.
the idea be to approach alzheimer 's with a strategy similar to that use for heart disease and other condition say laurie ryan program director for alzheimer 's disease clinical trial at the national institute on aging part of the n.i.h.
we 're go to look at people at risk just like we do with people who have high cholesterol and be at risk for cardiovascular disease she say
if we intervene now can we prevent or at least delay the disease
the $ 33.2 million grant part of the government 's national alzheimer 's plan will help finance a clinical trial to test a treatment on people 60 to 75 who have no symptom of the disease but do have two copy of a gene know to greatly increase the risk of get it as people age
the project lead by dr. eric m. reiman and dr. pierre n. tariot of the banner alzheimer 's institute in phoenix will test a drug or placebo on 650 adult in several location mostly in the united states
all of the participant will have two copy of the gene apoe4 have inherit it from both parent
study have find that more than half the people with two apoe4 gene will develop alzheimer 's compare with about one fourth of people with one copy and 10 percent of people with no copy
people with two copy also develop symptom earlier around age 68 year before most people with one copy and more than a decade before most people without the gene
people with two apoe4 gene make up only about 3 percent of the population but because they develop the conventional late onset form of alzheimer 's they be important to study
about 25 percent of people possess one copy of the gene
the banner project have not yet choose the drug to be test but it will be a treatment that attack amyloid a protein that accumulate in plaque in the brain of people with alzheimer 's
expect to begin in 2015 the project will ultimately cost more than $ 100 million most of which be expect to be finance by the pharmaceutical industry with some money from nonprofit source dr. reiman say
researcher will use sophisticated test to measure whether the drug help delay memory or cognitive decline over five year although dr. reiman say the test may be able to record some result in as little as two year
the study will also measure brain and neurological change over time
jamie tyrone 53 a retired nurse in ramona calif. say she feel traumatize when she learn while participate in a different research effort that she have two copy of apoe4
for the first time i feel hopeful she say
while too young to participate in the trial she recently form a nonprofit organization call beating alzheimer 's by embrace science babes which will soon have its inaugural fund raiser feature the celebrity helen reddy and marilu henner
she say the new trial mean so much to me because if this study have a positive outcome guess what i can be treat and i do not have to live in fear anymore
the new grant be the late of several grant for alzheimer 's prevention study
in 2012 the n.i.h. award $ 16 million to a project lead by the same researcher and dr. francisco lopera a colombian neurologist
the researcher will test an anti amyloid drug on member of a colombian family the large extend family in the world with a gene mutation that cause them to develop alzheimer 's early show cognitive impairment by around age 45
in that trial expect to start this year family member as young as 30 will receive the drug crenezumab manufacture by genentech which be finance the large portion of that $ 100 million trial
earlier this year the n.i.h. give a significant grant to a study that like the banner trial will focus on people at risk for common late onset alzheimer 's
lead by dr. reisa sperling who run the alzheimer 's program at brigham and women 's hospital in boston the trial will test the anti amyloid drug solanezumab on 1,000 people in various location who do not have symptom of alzheimer 's but do have amyloid plaque in their brain
the three year trial will receive about $ 7 million in federal money its first year and a possible total of $ 36 million
on wednesday the n.i.h. also award $ 1.5 million to a trial of three anti amyloid drug on people with rare gene mutation that lead to early onset alzheimer 's
the trial run by the dominantly inherited alzheimer network lead by dr. randall bateman of washington university in st. louis may receive a total of $ 6 million over four year
dr. ronald petersen director of the mayo clinic 's alzheimer 's center who be not involve in these prevention trial say the study complement each other and have the potential to answer question about the role of amyloid as a potential cause of alzheimer 's and whether attack it can prevent dementia
that do not mean we abandon people who need treatment dr. petersen say
but from a public health perspective if you want to prevent million of people from get the disease this be the way we have to go

pandora media win a battle in its continue war with the music industry over royalty when a federal judge rule on tuesday that the american society of composers authors and publishers which represent thousand of member can not prevent pandora from license all the song in its catalog
the ruling by judge denise l. cote of united states district court in manhattan be a blow to music publisher who have try to get the best royalty rate for digital music by limit the extent that perform right society like ascap and broadcast music incorporate represent their song
the ruling could also hurt the society themselves if they be perceive as prevent the publisher from get high rate
two year ago the industry 's big publisher begin withdraw digital right to their music from ascap and bmi force company like pandora to negotiate directly for a license to stream the music
sony/atv the world 's large publisher have say it receive a 25 percent high rate by license its song to pandora directly
pandora argue in a motion for summary judgment that allow publisher to withdraw their digital right violate ascap 's longtime consent decree which say that the organization must license its song to any service that ask
the judge agree say that ascap must make all the song in its catalog available to pandora through 2015 when its current licensing term with internet radio provider expire
if ascap license a song for some purpose the judge rule it must for others like stream as well
â'all mean all judge cote write in her decision
the ruling precede a large rate set trial between pandora and ascap which will begin on dec. 4
in a statement christopher harrison pandora 's assistant general counsel say we hope this will put an end to the attempt by certain ascap member publisher to unfairly and selectively withhold their catalog from pandora
john lofrumento ascap 's chief executive say he look forward to the trial
the court 's decision to grant summary judgment on this matter have no impact on our fundamental position in this case that songwriter deserve fair pay for their work an issue that the court have not yet decide
the large effect of the ruling be unclear
on wednesday a spokesman for sony/atv say he expect that the term of the deal would not change because of judge cote 's ruling
bmi which like ascap represent a huge portion of the music available in the united states operate under its own consent decree and be govern by a different federal rate court
bmi sue pandora in june over rate a few day after pandora say it would buy a small radio station in south dakota to qualify for rate enjoy by terrestrial broadcaster
ascap have also ask the federal communications commission to block that sale
pandora which have more than 70 million regular user be once the darling of the music world
but over the last year it have become one of industry 's big opponent as it push for low royalty rate
last year it heavily promote the internet radio fairness act a fail bill in congress that could have reduce what service like pandora pay record company and perform artist

should i turn it into a second bedroom
a."when someone can see that the dining area can become a second bedroom it ' a plus for resale say mady faber an associate real estate broker with town residential in manhattan
for a grow family or a couple be able to buy a one bedroom that can be convert to a two bedroom mean they can stay there for many more year if they have a baby or need to work at home

and move ahead with the conversion before list the property can make the home even more appealing
just make sure you really do have enough space she say because aesthetically if the living room be small and you cut off the dining area to create a second bedroom it may seem cramped
and that could turn off potential buyer
the kitchen should also have a separate entrance that be not through the new bedroom so the flow of space do not feel awkward
there be several other basic requirement the space must meet to be consider a true second bedroom say james ramsey owner of the new york design firm raad.
the first be adequate light and air he say mean the space need a window

and there ' a minimum dimension of eight foot that you need for the width of your bedroom he say
in his soho apartment mr. ramsey recently transform a dining nook into a bedroom for his year old son
it ' basically a room that ' calculate to be the minimum size you need for a twin size bed a crib and a set of dresser that you can change the baby on top of he say

a permanent wall be one option mr. ramsey note but a pressurized wall a temporary partition that be not permanently fasten to structural member so it can be more easily remove in the future would also work

take daniel myers a retire lawyer who move in with his wife jill in 1993 when he be 60
now he say i can not get on the roof to get the leaf off and i can not chop wood
and needless to say there have be plenty of compromise along the way
even something as simple as cut down a tree or buy a new dishwasher require a consensus or at least the agreement of three quarter of the resident
and get that many people to agree on anything can take a while
ask sophie otis a clinical psychologist who be now 77 who have to lobby for almost two decade to get rid of the tree obstruct the view from her window
in 1993 when she move in it be only six foot tall and she could see around it

in some respect 1988 have the feel of an alien distant era
there be no such thing as the world wide web then
the soviet union be still around the berlin wall still stand
americans elect a republican president who would raise tax to help tame the budget deficit
on tuesday however the census bureau remind me how for most americans 1988 still look a lot like yesterday last year the typical household make $ 51,017 roughly the same as the typical household make a quarter of a century ago
the statistic be staggering hardly what one would expect from one of the rich and most technologically advanced nation on the planet
i have write several time before about how measure of social and economic well being in the united states have slip compare to other advanced country
but it be even more poignant to recognize that in many way america have be stand still for a full generation
it make me wonder what happen to progress
consider 36 year ago this month when nasa launch the voyager 1 probe into space 11.6 percent of americans be officially consider poor
the other day voyager sail clear out of the solar system into interstellar space the first man make object to do so record its environment on an 8-track deck
use the same official metric which actually undercounts the poor compare to new method use by the census today the poverty rate be 15 percent
to be sure we have make progress over the last 25 year
the nation 's gross domestic product per person have increase 40 percent since 1988
we have gain four year worth of life expectancy at birth
the infant mortality rate have plummet by 50 percent
more woman and more man be enter and graduate from college
we also have access to far more sophisticated consumer good from the iphone to car pack with digital device
and the cost of many basic staple notably food have fall significantly
carl shapiro an economist at the university of california berkeley and an expert on technology and innovation who step down from president obama 's council on economic advisors last year call the progress in information technology and biotechnology over the last 25 year breathtaking
most americans partake in the benefit offer by these new technology from smartphones to better dental care professor shapiro say
still he acknowledge somehow this impressive progress have not translate into great economic security for the american middle class
in key respect in fact the standard of living of most americans have fall decidedly behind
just take the cost of medical service
health care spend per person adjust for inflation have roughly double since 1988 to about $ 8,500 push up health insurance premium and eat into worker wage
the cost of go to college have be rise faster than inflation as well
about two third of people with bachelor 's degree rely on loan to get through college up from 45 percent two decade ago
average student debt in 2011 be $ 23,300
in contrast to people in other developed nation who have devote more time to leisure as they have get rich americans work about as much as they do a quarter century ago
despite all this toil the net worth of the typical american family in the middle of the income distribution fall to $ 66,000 in 2010 6 percent less than in 1989 after inflation
though the bursting of the housing bubble and ensue great recession take a big share of the blame for family weakening finance it be nonetheless startle that a single financial event only a hiccup on the road to prosperity of americans on the top of the pile could erase a generation worth of progress for those in the middle
though the statistic may be startle the story they tell be unfortunately not surprising
it be the story of america 's new normal
in the new normal the share of the nation 's income channel to corporate profit be high than at any time since the 1920s while worker share languishes at its low since 1965
in the new normal the real wage of worker on the factory floor be low than they be in the early 70
and the rich 10 percent of americans get over half of the income america produce
almost all of the benefit of growth since the trough of the great recession have be go to those in the upper class say timothy smeeding who head the institute for research on poverty at the university of madison wisconsin

middle- and low income family be get a small slice of a small economic pie as labor market have change drastically during our recovery
this story be about three decade old
in 2010 the department of commerce publish a study about what it would take for different type of family to achieve the aspiration of the middle class which it define as a house a car or two in the garage a vacation now and then decent health care and enough saving to retire and contribute to the child 's college education
it conclude that the middle class have become a much more exclusive club
even two earner family make almost $ 81,000 in 2008 substantially more than the family median of about $ 60,000 report by the census would have a much tough time acquire the attribute of the middle class than in 1990
the income of these type of family actually rise by a fifth between 1990 and 2008 accord to the report
they be more educate and work more hour on average and have child at a late age
still that be no match for the 56 percent jump in the cost of housing the 155 percent leap in out of pocket spending on health care and the double digit increase in the cost of college
so either we define the middle class down a couple of notch or we acknowledge that the middle class be not in the middle anymore

it use to be that if you could not afford to pay a big medical bill your doctor or hospital may let you pay it over time a little bit each month
the holston medical group for instance a large multispecialty physician group in tennessee have one plan with such low payment that it would have take the patient 115 year to pay a bill off
but the day of such informal arrangement may be number
you can still find installment plan but now they be often more structured agreement manage by a company hire to oversee your account
hospital say they be turn to such business because as insurance plan shift more cost to patient provider be stuck try to collect money they be owe
hospital provide about $ 41 billion in uncompensated care in 2011 accord to the american hospital association
some hospital have even come under fire for heavy handed practice like put representative of collection agency in emergency room to get patient to pay up front
enter service like carepayment and clearbalance which promote no interest payment plan to hospital and patient as flexible and patient friendly
hospital be very sensitive to the fact that out of pocket cost for patient be increase drastically say craig froude chief executive of carepayment
they 're try to figure out how to adapt
detail vary depend on the term negotiate between the hospital and the payment company
in some case hospital offer the plan as an option
other hospital automatically enroll patient who do not pay a bill within 90 day
typically the company offer plan of as long as two year and sometimes as long as five year with no interest or fee for patient
payment be usually base on a percentage of the total bill with minimum around $ 25 a month
the hospital pay a fee to the company in exchange for get its payment up front
the company then collect the payment
some offer automatic deduction and let patient check their account online
the benefit be that hospital may get more of the money they be owe than they would otherwise even after factor in fee to the outside company
the patient get time to pay a big bill and avoid the damage to a credit record that would occur if the debt be send to collection
that can still happen
if the patient do not pay the company send the account back to the hospital for review
a patient who use such a plan may receive a card bear the name of the hospital and the payment firm but it be not a credit card
the company say they may conduct a soft inquiry on a patient 's credit report which do not affect the credit score
a patient whose score fall below a certain level will still be put on a plan but the company will not pay the hospital until the patient have make a few payment on time
a patient 's payment record generally be not report to credit bureau
mitch patridge chief executive of csi financial services which be base in san diego and offer clearbalance say it give patient the option of have their payment history report to credit bureau if they choose to help build credit
jeff costello chief financial officer at beacon health system in south bend ind. say it have try offer short term payment plan and even low interest loan through a local bank but patient do not like pay interest for medical bill
the system begin use carepayment 's no interest plan in 2009 and it have be well receive by patient he say some who use it once ask for it up front when seek additional care
patient can add new bill to the account he say and have their monthly payment recalculate
here be question to ask about medical installment plan â
will i have to pay interest if i do not pay off the bill by a certain date
some provider include dentist and eye care outlet offer true credit card financing
they may offer zero percent rate but the rate can skyrocket if you be late or stop pay
hospital say their plan be different and offer no or in some case very low interest
but make sure you understand the detail of any plan you accept and get a copy of the agreement in writing so you know what happen if you can not pay
â
can i still get financial assistance if i agree to a payment plan
you should always ask first about financial help to reduce your overall bill say mark rukavina a specialist on medical debt
under the affordable care act nonprofit hospital will have to develop write policy on their charity care and collection practice
many for profit hospital have write policy too
you should ask
â should i use a no interest plan even if i can pay in full
some provider offer significant discount if you pay in full within 30 day
if you can do so that may be a better option

but continue to put the program in place and maintain public support for it will be among ms. merkel 's big challenge should she win a third term as chancellor in sunday 's election
ms. merkel of the traditionally conservative and pro business christian democrats come up with her plan in 2011 in the emotional aftermath of the fukushima nuclear disaster in japan
it envision shutting down all of germany 's nuclear plant by 2022 and shift almost entirely to wind and solar power by 2050

philadelphia in august 2005 my son alec then 39 year old collapse into unconsciousness while walk his dog in the suburb of philadelphia
by the time he arrive at the hospital his heart rate have slow to 30 beat per minute
fortunately an experienced physician recognize that alec be have a cardiac complication of lyme infection
installation of a pacemaker and an infusion of antibiotic save his life
each year there be more than 30,000 case of lyme disease report to the centers for disease control and prevention
but last month the c.d.c. announce that the real number of annual infection be close to 300,000
alec have one of the most serious consequence of a lyme infection but the microbe can also lead to neurological illness like meningitis and encephalitis and more commonly fatigue arthritis and rash
but the symptom can be hard to spot
indeed day before he become gravely ill alec consult a physician because of a rash but because it do not appear in a bull' eye shape lyme disease be not suspect
it be a common misconception that the lyme disease rash always appear this way
the tick that carry lyme disease which be prevalent in the northeast united states the upper midwest and northern california as well as in central europe and scandinavia can be hard to spot too
both nymph and adult tick can transmit the bacteria but the tiny nymph which emerge in the springtime be hard to see with the naked eye until they mature in the fall
in other word it ' easy to be bite and not realize it
if you be infect it ' easy for a doctor to miss the symptom
should not there be a vaccine for such a prevalent and dangerous disease
in fact we use to have one and be perfectly capable of produce another if the public demand be high and we avoid the mistake of the past
in 1998 smithkline beecham now glaxosmithkline develop a vaccine that be about 80 percent effective for at least a year after three dos
but the advisory committee on immunization practices which counsel the c.d.c. on vaccine use be lukewarm about the real benefit and necessity of it
the committee make a weak recommendation to consider vaccination for high risk person overlook the fact that plenty of casual gardener and hiker be be infect
instead the committee emphasize the use of protective clothing and insect repellent despite little evidence that those measure prevent tick bite and even less evidence that people will constantly use them
nevertheless the vaccine be put on the market and physician have to decide what to do with the ambiguous recommendation
then the manufacturer make a strategic error of its own decide to directly advertise the vaccination to the public despite the fact that by and large people rely on their doctor recommendation to decide whether to receive a vaccine
in addition the manufacturer put the vaccine on the market before it have be test in child so it could be prescribe only to adult
but the big blow to the marketing campaign come from a group of volunteer who have be involve in the vaccine 's prelicensure study and who report develop arthritic symptom after the vaccination
although the rate of arthritis in the vaccinated volunteer be the same as the rate in the control group some lyme disease activist conclude that the vaccine cause rather than prevent lyme disease
in 1999 a class action suit be bring against the manufacturer
retrospective study have show no connection between the vaccination and arthritis but at the time sale of the vaccine drop precipitously and in 2002 the manufacturer withdraw it from the market
of course lyme disease do not go away
the tick that carry the lyme bacteria be spread to new area
and though early antibiotic treatment can kill the lyme bacteria the diagnosis be frequently miss at the beginning of the disease as in my son 's case
we need to prevent people from get lyme disease in the first place
the experience of glaxo have unfortunately frightened other company away from pursue this need vaccine
i be a consultant to most of the major vaccine manufacturer though i have no financial interest in the development of a lyme vaccine and i have long be argue for a return to this area
despite the manufacturer reluctance scientific study have continue and experimental vaccine against lyme infection be available for further development
if manufacturer think there be a market for them they will work to obtain a license from the food and drug administration but first they must be convince that the fiasco of the first vaccine will not be repeat
physician and patient should write to the c.d.c. to remind them of high public demand
it be likely that a new vaccine would now be recommend for all those who work or play outdoors in the area where lyme bearing tick be common a large part of the population of the united states
until then americans can vaccinate their dog against lyme disease but have no such option for themselves

brussels the european union 's top financial regulator propose tough rule for market benchmark new oversight that come after a wave of interest rate rigging scandal at big bank
but the plan represent a step back from earlier proposal which call for a single regulator to oversee certain benchmark
the effort by the european commission come after a multiyear investigation by global regulator into whether financial firm manipulate key interest rate before and after the financial crisis to improve their profit and deflect scrutiny about their health
the fallout from the inquiry which lead to multibillion dollar fine and criminal charge prompt a public outcry for change to the rate set process
under the proposal by the commission national regulator would have the power to investigate possible rigging or conflict of interest
if they find wrongdoing they could impose fine of up to 10 percent of a firm 's annual revenue
the new rule which would cover a wide range of benchmark in area like energy and currency derivative financial contract and mortgage would also require bank and other contributor of data use in set the benchmark to sign a legally binding code of conduct to be enforce by national supervisor
market confidence have be undermine by scandal and allegation of benchmark manipulation michel barnier the european union commissioner for financial service say in a statement on wednesday
today 's proposal will ensure for the first time that all benchmark provider have to be authorize and supervise
but the plan which still need approval by european union government and the european parliament stop short of other initiative
earlier this year the government of britain make rate rig a criminal offense as part of a broad overhaul
british regulator now oversee the rate set process for the london interbank offer rate or libor a key benchmark at the center of the scandal
face objection from britain and part of the finance sector the commission back away from earlier plan to put the european securities and markets authority in charge of day to day supervision of various benchmark
instead the agency could have the authority to settle disagreement on major issue among national financial supervisor who oversee the setting of some benchmark
the proposal arguably involve unnecessary europeanization of the supervision of a benchmark the oversight of which have already be reform by the u.k. authorities say barney reynolds a partner at the law firm shearman sterling in london who advise client on european and british financial regulation refer to libor
some member of the european parliament vow to strengthen the rule by put a european agency in charge
the european parliament must now seek to revise the commission 's halfhearted proposal say sven giegold a german member of parliament and spokesman for finance issue for the greens party
this imply ensure european supervision of key benchmark

minerva n.y. a 250-foot waterfall one of the tall in the northeast tumble over giant slab of marble
a chain of 13 crystalline lake and pond teem with bass and lake trout
a 10-mile stretch of the hudson river gorge wind through dense stand of hemlock white pine and red maple
these natural feature make up the more than 21,000 acre of the adirondacks that be recently purchase by new york state from the nature conservancy a nonprofit organization
by october the land will be entirely open to the public for the first time in more than a century
it be now part of the forest preserve allow visitor to experience a resplendent landscape in the heart of the six million acre state park
but while environmentalist town official paddler boater hiker and snowmobilers have embrace the pristine wilderness they now find themselves in a tug of war over how the land should be enjoy
should it be reserve for quiet recreation like canoe raft and hiking

it be a debate that have long tear at the adirondacks and it revolve around an invisible entity noise

it ' a balancing act
you have to respect both objective
the question come down to whether the adirondack park agency which govern land use in the park should designate the land as wilderness which prohibit the use of motorize vehicle or wild forest which allow them
the nature conservancy have remain neutral but several other environmental group include protect the adirondacks the adirondack council and the adirondack mountain club be press for a wilderness designation
the land be part of a much large acquisition in 2007 by the nature conservancy which purchase 161,000 acre from a local timber company
the $ 110 million deal which include 90 mountain peak and 300 lake and pond be hail as a milestone in the history of adirondack park a remote patchwork of private and public land in upstate new york
after meet with local official and resident the nature conservancy decide to preserve 92,000 acre as active timberland through sustainable logging a move that use the state purchase of development right to save both job and the land 's open character
the group also win a commitment from the state to buy 65,000 acre in installment over five year and add them to the forest preserve which be off limit to development and logging
this first section to be buy by the state be break up into a few parcel
the debate center mainly on the large of them a 17,320-acre area know as the essex chain of lake tract a network of lake and pond in essex county as well as a 925-acre stretch of land along the indian river
there be several different proposal for those two parcel allow vary level of motorize access
another 2,780 acre that include the waterfall call ok slip falls would be classify as wilderness under each alternative
in a study of the 200 large lake in the adirondacks protect the adirondacks determine that only a dozen be off limit to motorboat and float plane
half of those be difficult to access require long hike through wood
the group be lobby for alternative 1a which it call wilderness with access allow visitor of all ability to park their car within a short hike of the essex lake chain

wild forest but with a special management area that would provide flexibility to limit motor use

lyme disease begin with the transmission of bacteria through the bite of a black legged tick and can spread to muscle joint the heart and even the brain

their work be recognize in 1985 with the ciba geigy ilar rheumatology prize a prestigious honor in arthritis research
in present the award dr. george e. ehrlich a vice president at ciba geigy the pharmaceutical giant hail the achievement as a truly magnificent piece of medical detective work

the story begin in fall 1975 when two mother one from lyme conn. the other from adjacent old lyme be distress by the odd rash neurological symptom and swollen joint that their family and others be experience

the case have also occur almost exclusively in warm weather month
here be a disease that by its clustering it be cluster in time it be cluster in space it be cluster in family and on road it really look like there be a vector something that transmit the disease such as an insect dr. malawista be quote as say in the book bull's eye unravel the medical mystery of lyme disease
yale university press 2003 by dr. jonathan a. edlow
the researcher report on the peculiar clustering and name it lyme arthritis dr. malawista 's idea in the journal arthritis and rheumatism in january 1977
a second article six month later suggest that antibiotic could help in some case but not in others which be still medicine 's essential view
dr. malawista and his team make the compelling link between tick and the disease by note that case be 30 time more frequent on the east side of the connecticut river where lyme be situate than on the west side

he do allow people at least the potential for a lot of autonomy dr. steere say
but the yale researcher be wrong in their initial judgment that the disease be cause by a virus and even wrong that it be truly a new disease
their announcement that it be cause by only one type of tick do not bear out
when symptom turn out to be much more diverse than arthritis they change the name to lyme disease
nonetheless their effort to study a malady that be soon cause anguish well beyond connecticut put them at the center of lyme disease research
in 1984 yale hold the first international conference on the disease
dr. willy burgdorfer work for the national institutes of health in montana find the bacterium that cause lyme disease in 1982
yale scientist then develop a vaccine which be license in 1998
it be take off the market in 2002
lyme disease remain treatable if not always curable
an antibiotic treatment usually wipe out the infection
if it do not another course of antibiotic may be administer sometimes intravenously
but bacteria can persist in the body cause harm and illness month or even year after treatment have end

a new study provide the best evidence yet that wear a back brace will slow the progression of the most common form of scoliosis in adolescent help them avoid painful spine surgery
physician have recommend brace for more than 50 year but until now study of its effectiveness have produce mixed result
the united states preventive services task force recommend against scoliosis screening in school partly on the ground that there be insufficient evidence that brace and other conservative treatment relieve back pain or improved quality of life in these child
the new randomized study publish on thursday in the new england journal of medicine should end the longstanding debate several expert say and may spur the task force to reconsider its position
the trial be very convincing say dr. b. stephens richards a pediatric orthopedic surgeon at texas scottish rite hospital in dallas
it scientifically prove that brace treatment work for adolescent with scoliosis who be at risk of curve worsen to the point of need surgery
adolescent girl be more likely than boy to have idiopathic scoliosis or curvature of the spine from no known cause
rigid bracing be wear to restore spine alignment by external force
it be a demand treatment at a vulnerable time of life
when you have a teenager who be anxious about wear a brace to school or what their friend will think it give us a bit of heartache to try to convince them if we be not certain ourselves say dr. paul d. sponseller the director of orthopedic surgery at johns hopkins children 's center who be not involve in the study

in light of this new evidence we can say we really do have a basis for put them through brace
in the study researcher analyze data on 242 patient at 25 site across the united states and canada
the child be all age 10 to 15 and still grow and they all have a spinal curvature of 20 to 40 degree
of those patient 116 be randomly assign to observation or brace for at least 18 hour daily
because too few family agree to randomization the researcher add a group of 126 adolescent who choose for themselves between bracing and observation
bracing be deem a failure if spinal curvature progress to 50 degree or more a point at which surgery be often suggest
it be deem a success if the child achieve skeletal maturity without this degree of curve progression
the trial be stop early because of the apparent efficacy of brace
in the analysis that include both group the rate of treatment success be 72 percent among child with bracing compare with 48 percent among those under observation
the benefit increase the longer brace be wear
more than 90 percent of the child who be successfully treat wear their brace more than 13 hour a day
dr. richards the immediate past president of the scoliosis research society say the study 's strength be the inclusion criterion limited to adolescent most at risk for spinal curve progression and the use of a high tech temperature sensitive device in the brace to measure compliance objectively
there be a lot of doctor like me who treat scoliosis as the primary focus of their practice who have doubt about whether brace be effective say dr. stuart l. weinstein the lead author of the study and a professor of orthopedic surgery at the university of iowa
now the jury be in
bracing have be the standard of care since the 1940
it take so long to perform a rigorous trial of its effectiveness not only because it be a gargantuan task say joe o'brien the president of the national scoliosis foundation but also because parent do not want to just sit there and wait and watch

such a study raise moral challenge too

ethically you have to accept that some patient will be randomized to not use a brace and your presumption be they will end up need surgery say dr. john t. smith a professor in the orthopedics department at the university of utah
when her daughter maddie be give a scoliosis diagnosis at age 10 becky houser of north liberty iowa want to avoid surgery at all cost
so maddie a participant in dr. weinstein 's study choose to wear a brace
we do not want to not do anything say mrs. houser who manage rental property
thirty year ago she undergo surgery for scoliosis herself spend three week in a hospital and nine month in an upper body cast
after three year of wear baggy top and yoga pant to school to accommodate the brace maddie now 13 be thrill to learn that her spinal curvature be hold steady at 28 degree
with no more major growth spurt leave she no longer need brace
we be extremely relieved mrs. houser say
a common surgical treatment spinal fusion entail put screw and rod in the spine to straighten it
the procedure have greatly improve but young patient still face risk like infection bone healing problem and rarely paralysis
despite the apparent success of brace the study do not pinpoint which child be most likely to benefit from it
indeed the researcher find that outcome be successful in 41 percent of the intervention group even though they seldom wear the brace
conversely erica shumaker a high school freshman in tipton iowa wear her brace 22 hour a day while participate in the study
yet her spinal curvature progress and she be likely to need surgery
her brace be not help as much as they think it would say her father rick shumaker

but there ' nothing we would do any different

and in few way have that belief be more test than in his frustrating private correspondence with the leader of iran a country with which the united states have have no diplomatic tie for 34 year
this week mr. obama indicate that he may finally have find a pen pal in tehran
at the core of iran 's recent diplomatic charm offensive a process that have include the release of 11 prominent political prisoner and a series of conciliatory statement by top iranian official be an exchange of letter confirm by both side between mr. obama and president hassan rouhani

ayatollah khamenei send a reply but fail to take mr. obama up on his offer

the ensue bloody crackdown all but snuff out diplomacy for the next year

now they 're send them to rouhani

to make that plan work analyst say it would be helpful for iran as the staunch regional ally of president bashar al assad of syria to play a constructive role
whether that be possible be highly questionable of course
but it give mr. obama a broad diplomatic context in which to engage mr. rouhani
the united states have generally insist on negotiate with iran purely on its nuclear program which have leave both side with little to talk about after the inevitable clash over the number of centrifuge or the amount of enrich uranium that the iranians be produce
at the end of the day obama stumble into diplomacy because of what happen with syria say trita parsi president of the national iranian american council who have write a book about mr. obama 's diplomatic effort a single roll of the dice

none of this should be a big surprise

angela merkel have a reputation as something of an enigma
biographer commentator and political opponent have create a cottage industry of merkel astrology around a leader that everyone find hard to read
with a general election schedule in germany for sunday a poll at which the chancellor be likely to win a mandate for a third term speculation be rife about merkel 's political course especially on foreign policy
but contrary to widely hold belief the chancellor 's position be in fact not all that difficult to identify
merkel have basically make three fundamental decision that have define the structure of her foreign policy
the first decision be to ensure that germany reject any kind of geopolitical ambition
the country have be a very useful enabler of the european union 's foreign policy in the western balkans but it have shy away from strengthen europe 's diplomatic or military capability in more substantial structural way
the same be true for nato where germany have forward a number of initiative on technical issue but be see as disengage from the big strategic discourse on the future of the western alliance in a change global security landscape
merkel have unenthusiastically heed old german military commitment in afghanistan and kosovo but she have keep germany firmly out of entanglement in the new type of crisis management operation that be emerge from the crisis in libya mali and syria
in all of this she can feel safely in agreement with the overwhelming majority of the german public
in the absence of large more global ambition what matter most in assess merkel 's foreign policy be her decision in relation to europe
this be where the crisis of the european single currency have force her against her instinct to become a decisive player and a risk taker
it be in this field that merkel 's other two fundamental foreign policy decision fall and it be here that her foreign policy legacy will be define
her second decision be to turn the euro zone into a de facto transfer union lite by guarantee the currency 's survival with pledge of billion of german taxpayer euro
in return she have since be push for immediate structural economic reform in the recipient country combine with medium- to long term project such as fiscal union and joint oversight instrument like the european stability mechanism
a bank union be still in limbo but may complete the picture in the not so distant future
all of these effort have one thing in common more or less strict oversight over a nation 's financial and economic policy
none of this would have be thinkable only a few year ago
this mean in simple term that merkel have preside over a substantial deepening of e.u. economic integration
with the measure she have take to remedy the crisis now firmly in place the european union have integrate faster and more substantially than in any previous five year period
true most of this have not be wholly voluntarily
much of it be dictate by the crisis
but in the end it be largely merkel who design or enable these great integrationist leap forward
merkel 's third decision be perhaps the most fateful one
the german chancellor have determine that she favor a politically less integrate europe after the crisis
in august she announce in a radio interview that now be the time to think about give some power back from brussels to the member state
she do not go into specific but add that europe from now on would not necessarily require more common policy with decision make by the brussels base institution
improve governance could be achieve through better coordination among member state
this victory for merkel 's long stand intergovernmental instinct over an age old german pro integration tradition be nothing less than revolutionary particularly when compare with the ideology of helmut kohl under whose tutelage she enter the political stage
perhaps it be mean to counterbalance the enormous push toward close economic integration
but it be clear that again merkel have ally herself with the majority of germans who think that europe 's economic side be great but that its political side be increasingly sinister
merkel 's third decision be risky
first of all it rest on the flawed assumption that economic and political integration can be separate from each other when the basic lesson of the euro crisis be that you can not have one without the other
second it fatefully tie her to the politically weaken british prime minister david cameron who share her vision of repatriate many government function and favor intergovernmental deal make over the e.u. 's classic community method but whose inability to control his own party be cause him existential problem at home
third merkel 's decision rip the very engine out of the entire integration idea that germany europe 's historically problematic core country underwrite the ever fragile idea of european politics transcend the merely national
of merkel 's three fundamental foreign policy decision strategic abstention be understandable but unsustainable in the long run her recipe to tackle the crisis be probably correct but could create severe collateral damage and her intergovernmental turn revolutionize the integration project by risk some of its historic achievement
expect merkel 's post election foreign policy to be build around these three foundation
if it work out which it could it be pure genius
if not generation from now historian will wonder what drive that enigmatic woman

the name myllokunmingia may not ring a bell but it be worth know
this 520-million year old creature be the size of a guppy with a tiny swordfish like fin run high over its back
the fossil it have leave behind preserve trace of a skull
human have a skull too
this and a number of other trait we share with myllokunmingia reveal it to be one of the old most primitive vertebrate yet find
it be in other word a hint of where we come from
myllokunmingia emerge during one of the most important phase in the history of life an evolutionary boom know as the cambrian explosion name for the geological period when it take place
over the course of about 20 million year the old know fossil of most of the major group of live animal appear reveal a rapid diversification of life that lead directly to human
it ' rapid in geological term but it ' probably not rapid to anyone who ' not a geologist say paul smith the director of the oxford museum of natural history
by some estimate the first animal evolve about 750 million year ago
but it ' not until around 520 million year ago that many major group of live animal leave behind their first fossil
for decade scientist have search for the trigger that set in motion this riot of diversity in the animal kingdom
recently dr. smith and his colleague david harper of the university of durham take a look at the hypothesis that have be offer about what cause the cambrian explosion
it become apparent just how many hypothesis there be out there dr. harper say
thirty plus over the past 10 year
the scientist find that many of those explanation have boil the cause down to just one trigger
geologist suggest geological cause
ecologist propose ecological one
many of those idea have merit dr. smith and dr. harper argue in a commentary in this week 's science but it ' a mistake to search for a single cause
they propose that a tangle web of factor and feedback be responsible for evolution 's big bang
long before the cambrian explosion dr. smith and dr. harper argue one lineage of animal have already evolve the genetic capacity for spectacular diversity
know as the bilaterians they probably look at first like little crawl worm
they share the precambrian ocean with other animal like sponge and jellyfish
during the cambrian explosion relatively mod change to their gene give rise to a spectacular range of body
but those gene evolve in bilaterians ten of million of year before the cambrian explosion put them to the test note dr. smith
they have the capacity he say but it have not be express yet
it take a global flood to tap that capacity dr. smith and dr. harper propose
they base their proposal on a study publish last year by shanan peters of the university of wisconsin and robert gaines of pomona college
they offer evidence that the cambrian explosion be precede by a rise in sea level that submerge vast swath of land erode the drown rock
there ' a big kick that correlate with the sea level rise dr. smith say of the fossil record
he and dr. harper propose that this kick happen thanks to the new habitat create by the sea level rise
these shallow coastal habitat be bath in sunlight and nourish with erode nutrient like phosphate
animal colonize these new fertile habitat dr. smith and dr. harper argue and evolve to take up new ecological niche
but these great flood also poison the ocean
the erosion of the coastline release calcium which can be toxic to cell
in order to survive animal have to evolve way to rid themselves of the poison
one solution may have be to pack the calcium into crystal which eventually evolve into shell bone and other hard tissue
dr. smith do not think it ' a coincidence that several different lineage of bilaterians evolve hard tissue during the cambrian explosion and not sooner
these shell and other hard tissue speed up animal evolution even more
predator could grow hard claw and jaw for kill prey and their prey could evolve hard shell and spine to defend themselves
animal become lock in an evolutionary arm race
this new ecological food web grow even more complex
big predator evolve that could eat small predator
meanwhile some bilaterians burrow into the sea floor for the first time allow oxygen rich seawater to flow into the sediment
those first burrowers profoundly transform the world 's ocean create yet another habitat that other oxygen breathe animal could also invade
that drive the diversification onward say dr. smith
kevin peterson a biologist at dartmouth praise dr. smith and dr. harper for point to the right way to study the cambrian explosion
we be long past identify single trigger for the event he say
dr. peters agree that take a holistic view of the cambrian explosion would lead to a better understanding of it
it 'll be a fun next decade he predict
but philip donoghue of the university of bristol do not think the link dr. smith and dr. harper use in their hypothesis be tight enough yet
question still remain for example about how long vertebrate and other animal group already exist before they leave behind fossil like myllokunmingia
if animal diversify earlier then scientist will need to look at earlier cause
timing say dr. donoghue be everything

the conclusion publish in the journal science come from the fact that curiosity have be look for methane a ga that be consider a possible calling card of microbe and have so far find none of it
while the absence of methane do not rule out the possibility of present day life on mars there be plenty of microbe on earth at least that do not produce methane it do return the idea to the realm of pure speculation without any hopeful data to back it up

curiosity which have be trundle across the planet for a little over a year make measurement from martian spring to late summer come up empty for methane
scientist have long think that mars warm and wet in its early year could have be hospitable for life and the new finding do not mean that it be not
but that be about three and a half billion year ago
methane molecule break apart over a few century victim of the sun 's ultraviolet light and of chemical reaction in the atmosphere so any methane in the air from primordial time would have disappear long ago
that be why report of huge plume of methane rise over mars in 2003 fuel fresh hope for martian microbe
those finding base on data from telescope on earth and a spacecraft orbit mars set off a surge of speculation and scientific interest
on earth most of the methane come from micro organism know as methanogen but the ga be also produce without live organism in hydrothermal vent
either possibility would be a surprising result for mars
after the 2003 methane reading a lot people get excite and start work on it say christopher r. webster of nasa 's jet propulsion laboratory in pasadena calif. and the lead author of the paper in science

but it do not mean there be not pony out there

he say he now believe that methane on mars be episodic release in large plume and then quickly destroy

he be raise by his grandparent after his father shikanojo yamauchi desert the family

washington the obama administration on thursday expand its effort to curtail severe penalty for low level federal drug offense order prosecutor to refile charge against defendant in pending case and strip out any reference to specific quantity of illicit substance that would trigger mandatory minimum sentencing law
the move announce by attorney general eric h. holder jr. at a speech before the annual conference of the congressional black caucus build on a major policy change he unveil last month to avoid mandatory minimum sentencing law in future low level case
by reserve the most severe prison term for serious high level or violent drug trafficker or kingpin we can better enhance public safety mr. holder say
we can increase our focus on prove strategy for deterrence and rehabilitation
and we can do so while make our expenditure smarter and more productive
the policy apply to defendant who meet four criterion their offense do not involve violence the use of a weapon or sell drug to minor they be not leader of a criminal organization they have no significant tie to large scale gang or drug trafficking organization and they have no significant criminal history
on thursday the justice department order prosecutor to apply the new policy retroactively to defendant who be already in the system but have not yet be sentence
it be not immediately clear how many pending federal drug case would be affect
in case where a defendant have be charge but guilt have not yet be determine prosecutor will be direct to file replacement criminal complaint to eliminate reference to specific quantity of drug that would trigger a mandatory minimum sentence be the defendant to be convict accord to a three page justice department memorandum from mr. holder to federal prosecutor
mr. holder 's memorandum say that for case in which a defendant have already be find guilty but no sentence have yet be impose prosecutor have discretion about whether to apply the new policy
they be encourage to apply the policy in guilty plea case where legally and practically feasible he write but they should generally not seek relief for a defendant who choose to go to trial
the memo portray the policy as an exercise of prosecutorial discretion and direct justice department official to fight any motion by a convict but not yet sentence defendant to seek relief without the government 's consent on the basis of the new policy
the memo also say prosecutor should not disturb the sentence in a case in which sentence have be impose
the justice department policy follow effort pioneer in state include conservative lean texas and south carolina to control soar taxpayer money that be spend to incarcerate huge number of nonviolent offender
still those change be approve by state legislature
by contrast the obama administration be undertake its move without wait to see whether congress will approve legislation to restore great leeway to judge in sentencing
the wave of change come as crime have plummet to the low level in four decade lead to a bipartisan pendulum swing against the tough on crime policy impose a generation ago amid the crack cocaine epidemic
those policy result in an 800 percent increase in the number of prisoner in the united states at a time when the national population grow by only a third
mr. holder have repeatedly criticize the moral impact of the nation 's high incarceration rate emphasize that while the united states have only 5 percent of the world 's population it have 25 percent of its prisoner

at the sushi counter at kura there be no sentinel in white no silent coolly appraise overlord
norihiro ishizuka 70 stand alone wear not a crisp chef 's coat but a samue traditionally a monk 's work robe that slouch at his waist like a dress gown
he have a benevolent and slightly rakish air with his faint pencil mustache and white gray hair peek out of the bottom of his cap
he nod and grin already halfway to a laugh and the meal have not yet begin
outside kura 's east village shopfront be austere a blank wall crosshatch by the shadow of a fire escape with no sign save a linen drape hang in an archway ink with an unfinished circle
inside 12 seat line a blond wood counter
delicate jazz chime above
but this be not a shrine
behind mr. ishizuka be expose brick and the rough edge seem to suit him
no glass case separate him from diner instead fish be heap unceremoniously in a wide shallow basket
mr. ishizuka heft the fish up and slap it back down as if assemble sushi be a purely practical matter not require a soundtrack by philip glass
the great sushi chef of new york tend to be musical in their movement
think of masato shimizu of 15 east the curve of his finger as elegant as a cellist 's or eiji ichimura of ichimura at brushstroke bend intently over his creation like glenn gould and barely speak above a whisper
mr. ishizuka be more of a tony bennett a crooner work the crowd with a genial smile and a generous hand
he make sushi with substantial cut of fish tricky to eat in a single bite
alongside beautifully fresh kampachi tuna salmon and aji horse mackerel may be aka uni the large sweeter red sea urchin from the channel islands off california scallop balance on a band of nori over rice and saba mackerel present kyoto style fish and rice roll together in cloth and cut like slab of cake twice the height of ordinary sushi
keep in mind those rough edge
one evening the vein of fat in marble otoro be more resistant than yield ikura salmon roe be unchecked in its saltiness tamago a block of egg scramble with sugar sake and dashi be sweet without nuance
these seem less like misstep than choice come from a fondness for more direct flavor
soy sauce be provide but no wasabi
you will not miss it
instead there be tip of finger lime to be rub on the fish until their tiny juice sac squeeze out look like pale green roe and burst tartly in the mouth
all meal be omakase start at a reasonable $ 65 for 10 piece of nigiri and a hand roll which mr. ishizuka hand to you across the counter with a flourish soup aka dashi perhaps deepen with long ferment black miso and an appetizer tuna snowcapped with sticky mountain yam and stipple with nori dust say or creamy orange ankimo monkfish liver under grate daikon saturate red by chile
also available be osaka style kappo cook dish attune to the season less formal than kaiseki
these may include sesame tofu which be not tofu at all but a perfect cold cube of ground white sesame paste its taste at once familiar and ethereal and tuna tail brush with an understated teriyaki sauce char and strew with miniature rice cracker pearl
mr. ishizuka come from japan to new york in the late 1980 to preside at umeda near gramercy park then decamp to a restaurant in michigan
one of his partner at kura huey cheng work for him there as a waiter a role that mr. cheng 24 reprises here along with help to make the sushi rice and finish the kappo dish in the back kitchen
one night mr. ishizuka offer everyone at the counter shiokara an izakaya snack of fermented squid gut
i have eat the dish before and still it take my breath away like down a jigger of seawater intensely salty and fishy sop yet crunchy
other diner wince and giggle nervously
mr. ishizuka lean over to an old japanese gentleman at the counter
for the young one he say and they laugh
