the day my daughter arrive home from her first year in college her boyfriend move in
they do not consult me
one day i be happily live alone in my two bedroom seattle apartment and the next i have two teenage roommate one of whom i hardly know
the boyfriend who be still a high school senior have be my daughter 's summer fling before she leave for college last september
with my last child go i think i would be terribly sad and lonely
and i be for about 10 minute
after i have spend a brief stint lie on her bed mourn her childhood i do what my own mother have do i gather the stuff she have leave behind and move it to the basement storage unit
then i take over the office nook she have claim but hardly ever use and make it my own
i instal shelf and fill them with my reference book
i stock the refrigerator and cupboard with gluten free low fat food
i buy soap in scent that please me and shampoo that suit my hair type
i rearrange the furniture and clean the house from top to bottom
with each pas of the vacuum i find myself become cheerier
my husband have move to our farm on lopez island in the san juan islands of washington with our two dog to pursue his dream of be a homesteader change our marriage into a long distance arrangement with occasional weekend visit
i find myself for the first time in 35 year live alone in a perfectly tidy apartment
i love it
then in may the school year end and my daughter come home for the summer
after be away for so long she could barely wait to see her boyfriend
he move into her bedroom the night she arrive and hardly ever leave except to attend his last few class of high school
the two of them be so enamored of each other i do not have the heart to separate them
i assume they would soon grow bore with see each other every day and he would go home
this do not happen
the big problem be that my daughter and her boyfriend bring with them a level of messiness i have grow unaccustomed to
they shed clothing like dog shed fur pepper the apartment with sweatshirt t shirt and underwear
they prefer my shower to hers and soon the drain be clog with hair
while i be out of town on business they move into my bedroom too i have a king size bed and they find it roomy
they produce mound of laundry garbage and recycling
the water and electricity bill both shoot up
my daughter love cooking and decide that her summer job be to teach her boyfriend to cook
unfortunately their enthusiasm do not extend to clean up
i would arrive home from work to dirty dish and half fill pot and pan on the stove
the kitchen floor would be sticky the stovetop spatter with oil and the oven bottom crusty with burn food
when i ask if the boyfriend may help out a little by do dish or take out the compost my daughter say he ' phobic about get his hand dirty
i 'm sure that work well for him i reply

jhumpa lahiri first make her name with quiet meticulously observe story about indian immigrant try to adjust to new life in the united states story that have the hush intimacy of chamber music
the premise of her new novel the lowland in contrast be startlingly operatic
udayan an idealistic student in calcutta in the 1960 be draw into mao inspire revolutionary politics
after his violent death which happen fairly early in the novel his devoted dutiful brother subhash marry his pregnant widow gauri and bring her to america in hope of give her a new start in a new country
their marriage though will remain haunted by their memory of udayan and a terrible secret gauri keep to herself
the lowland be certainly ms. lahiri 's most ambitious undertaking yet and it eventually open out into a move family story
it be initially hobble however by page and page of historical exposition by a schematic plotline and by a disjunction between the author 's scrupulous lapidary prose and the dramatic dickensian event she recount
it be only in the second half that ms. lahiri 's talent for capture the small emotional detail of her character daily life take over immerse us in their story and make us less aware of the book 's creaky and often noisy hydraulics
in her 2003 novel the namesake as in her two collection of short story unaccustomed earth and the pulitzer prize win interpreter of maladies the life of ms. lahiri 's character be make palpably real to us through her exacting evocation of their day to day routine the wonder bread sandwich tint green with curry that a bengali mother make for her embarrassed daughter to take to school the careful adoption of american ritual like make snowman or dye easter egg
such particular accentuate the difference between immigrant parent and their american bear child and the almost existential sense of dislocation that exile can produce in people who feel at home neither in their ancestral country nor in the united states
while the reader come to know these earlier people as distinct individual the character in the lowland seem to have be conceive as representative type with designate role to play in a family melodrama construct to underscore generational pattern of resentment and redemption rootedness and freedom
udayan be the rebellious impulsive brother who make a series of reckless decision that will affect everyone who love him for decade to come
subhash be the nice rational brother who will spend much of his life deal with the fallout from his sibling 's heedless action
gauri be an angry selfish woman who will repay subhash 's generosity and kindness and his effort to invent a new life for them in rhode island with chilly disregard
subhash 's mother have try to dissuade him from marry gauri tell him that she ' udayan 's wife she will never love you
she also warn him that gauri be too withdrawn too aloof to be a mother
though this prophecy have be deliver by a woman embitter by the death of her favorite son it will turn out to be all too true gauri will abandon her daughter bela conceive with udayan and bring up by subhash as his own beloved child to pursue her own dream of study philosophy and build an academic career
ms. lahiri never manage to make this terrible act handle by gauri with cruelty and arbitrary highhandedness plausible understandable or viscerally feel
why would gauri regard motherhood and career as an either/or choice
why make no effort to stay in touch with bela or explain her decision to move to california
why not discuss her need to leave her marriage and her child with her husband
because ms. lahiri never give us real insight into gauri 's decision making or psychology she come across not as a flawed and complicated person but as a folk tale parody of a cold selfish witch who ' fulfil her nasty mother in law 's bad prediction
the reader often have the sense that ms. lahiri be try to fit her character into a predetermined narrative design which can make for diagrammatic and unsatisfying storytelling
what turn this novel around and ultimately seize the reader 's imagination be ms. lahiri 's deeply feel depiction of subhash 's relationship with bela his unwavering devotion to this good hearted little girl his bafflement as her grief over her mother 's abandonment lead her to withdraw from him as well his slow painful effort to rebuild a life for himself in the wake of gauri 's departure
it be in these late chapter that the cumbersome historical exposition and overarching narrative architecture fall away and ms. lahiri 's most shining gift as a writer come to the fore her ability to conjure the daily texture of people 's life her understanding of how their personal and cultural expectation have shape their choice her talent for map mood and inchoate emotion with pointillist precision
as this happen the character in the lowland with the qualified exception of gauri become fully human drive not by one identifiable trait like duty anger or rebellion but by a full spectrum of feeling and capable not only of rage and vexation but also of forgiveness and hope
by its end this ungainly novel remind us of ms. lahiri 's copious talent as a writer however imperfectly they be employ here

assume a loan be cheap than apply for a new one because there be few settlement fee
an appraisal be not require though a buyer may want to obtain one anyway
and in new york borrower assume a loan do not have to pay the hefty mortgage recording tax a second time mr. israel say
â f.h.a. loan do demand that the borrower pay for mortgage insurance over the life of the loan
but when assume a loan borrower do not have to pay the upfront mortgage insurance premium require on a new loan accord to john walsh the president of total mortgage services in milford conn.
and he note because the original mortgage holder would have be pay the loan for a number of year the buyer assume the loan will start at a point deeper into the amortization schedule than on a new loan
that mean more of the monthly payment will go toward principal
in a rise rate environment assumability be a very attractive option say katie miller the vice president of mortgage product for navy federal credit union
it end up make home that much more affordable
she emphasize however that loan assumption be often not a viable option for first time buyer if the seller have accumulate substantial equity in the home
say for example that the seller 's loan balance be $ 150,000 and the sale price for the property be $ 200,000
the borrower assume the loan must come up with the $ 50,000 difference either in cash or through some type of subordinate financing
that can be too big a hurdle for first time buyer
the more attractive option at navy federal be the homebuyers choice loan which offer 100 percent financing
these loan currently account for about a quarter of the credit union 's purchase volume and 65 percent of those borrower be first time buyer ms. miller say
borrower seek to assume a loan must also prove their creditworthiness as they would for any f.h.a. or v.a. loan
under f.h.a. rule once a new borrower be find to be creditworthy enough to assume a loan the lender must release the seller from any future liability for payment of that loan
borrower consider loan assumption should weigh the cost against other loan option pay attention to the principal and interest payment the amount of cash require upfront and the private mortgage insurance premium
at the end of the day mr. walsh say if the prospective buyer can come up with the down payment and qualify for the loan assumption then it could be a huge benefit

i have the odd feeling that i be watch a quiet finely etch indie movie on an iphone and lose too much of the detail
mr. lepage do supply some nifty directorial sleight of hand as when two white sheet slide slowly across the stage to indicate a thin layer of snowfall
and as always his integration of video imagery by david leclerc be seamless and sometimes witty
one interstitial segment appear to be an old style chinese martial art movie set in the legendary past until patty of fry chicken appear in the hand of the warrior it ' a chinese ad for kfc. the blue dragon end on a movingly ambiguous note
earlier xiao ling tell claire the grim legend of how woman with unwanted baby once dispose of them by throw them into the yangtze river and let the three gorge decide their fate a new family death by drown or a return to the place where they be abandon
evoke this legend mr. lepage and ms. michaud conclude the show by offer three provisional ending all plausible and rewarding on their own term but each leave one of the three character wave a bittersweet goodbye to the other two suggest that whatever the future hold someone will end up abandon and alone

san francisco kids
the reckless rant and picture they post online can often get them in trouble by compromise their chance of get into a good college or even land them in jail
what to do about such lapse vexes parent school official the internet company that host their word and image and the law
now california legislator be try to solve the problem with the first measure in the country to give minor the legal right to scrub away their online indiscretion
the legislation put the state in the middle of a turbulent debate over how best to protect child and their privacy on the internet and whether state should even be try to tame the web
the governor jerry brown have take no position on the bill
he have until mid october to sign it after which without his signature the legislation become law
california be often in the vanguard when it come to digital privacy
it be the first state to require company to report data breach and it require web site and mobile apps to post privacy policy that explain how personal information be use
a recently pass law require web site to tell user whether they honor browser do not track signal
the right to delete or eraser provision be part of a broad bill that prohibit web site which have actual knowledge that a minor be use the site base on a profile and activity on the site from run ad for a range of product include alcohol spray paint tattoo tanning bed and e cigarette
the eraser section compel online site to let user under 18 delete rant tweet picture status update and other material
although many company include facebook and twitter already offer this option to their user the california bill would make it a right across the internet for child who live in that state
kid and teenager often self reveal before they self reflect say james steyer chief executive of common sense media a san francisco base advocacy group that push for the law
it ' a very important milestone
the rash revelation by a texas teenager justin carter on facebook last february a threatened school shoot his family insist be sarcastic make in the heat of play a video game land him in a texas jail on a felony terrorism charge for nearly six month
his father jack favor the california legislation but wonder if it would go far enough
they should be allow to delete it but then again be it really delete
mr. carter 39 of san antonio say in an interview this week
also mr. carter say if his son have delete the conversation that someone report to the authorities would the deletion be see as destroy evidence
his son now 19 be out on a bond pending trial
any law try to tame the internet he say be likely to run into turbulence
it ' a whole new territory it grow fast than the law do mr. carter say
we 're try to come up with thing to make it all neat
there ' collateral damage my son be one of them
critic of an eraser law see pitfall
they warn that in try to protect child the law could unwittingly put them at risk by dig deeper into their personal life
to comply with the law for example company would have to collect more information about their customer include whether they be under 18 and whether they be in california
there be also practical concern
if other state pass similar law company would be force to devise multiple policy for the underage resident of different state confuse consumer and create unwieldy requirement for web business that be essentially stateless except for issue like collect sale tax
the internet opponent of the law say should be regulate by a uniform set of rule not piecemeal by the state
this be well mean legislation but there be concern about it say stephen balkam president of the family online safety institute which advise company like facebook and microsoft on online safety issue
mr. balkam say he favor congressional oversight in issue like child 's online privacy and if necessary regulation by the federal trade commission
where california lead others follow he say
i think it will be a mess
some supporter of the bill say internet company get off easy
the eraser bill do not for example require company to remove the delete data from its server altogether nor do it offer any way to delete material that have be share by others a sensational picture that have go viral in other word can not be purge from the internet
and it be nothing like the right to be forget measure that legislator in europe have be press for
that proposal would at its core allow all europeans not just child to delete their online personal information several amendment to the plan address freedom of expression concern
it ' an important first step but there ' more to be do mr. steyer say
mr. steyer 's organization which participate in a safety advisory group with facebook but soon leave after disagreement with the company 's approach have be push for more aggressive legislation
those effort in 2011 lead member of congress to propose a measure that would have allow parent to scrub material post by their child
criticize by free speech advocate the bill go nowhere though senator edward j. markey democrat of massachusetts who be a co sponsor plan to introduce it again later this year
short of federal privacy law in general state have be pass law on a host of privacy matter in many case follow california 's lead
often you need to comply with the most restrictive state as a practical matter because the internet do not really have state boundary say mali friedman a lawyer in the san francisco office of covington burling a national law firm
bank regulator around the world be force bank to hold more capital than they do before the financial crisis reveal just how inadequate their capital truly be
but one set of american bank appear to be on the verge of keep the right to have no capital at all
that group be the money market fund which function as bank but historically have have the best of all regulatory world no capital requirement no reserve no fee for deposit insurance and a belief by their customer that they be at least as safe as bank
this week the comment period close on proposed money market rule set forth by the securities and exchange commission
the rule be pitifully weak and inadequate
they could even make the system more vulnerable in a crisis as the president of all 12 federal reserve bank point out in a letter to the s.e.c.
but that have not stop the mutual fund industry from try to weaken them even more
by coincidence the deadline for comment be on thursday just five day after the fifth anniversary of the collapse of lehman brothers
it be that collapse that reveal to all just how shaky the money market industry be
the answer be or ought to be remarkably simple they either have to be bank or mutual fund paul a. volcker the former federal reserve chairman tell me in an interview
if they be bank promise to pay at par on demand they should be regulate like bank
if they be mutual fund they should be regulate like mutual fund
but such a sensible proposal would outrage the money market fund industry which have lobby politician intensely
it be perhaps the big embarrassment of mary schapiro 's tenure as chairwoman of the s.e.c. that she be unable to persuade a majority of commissioner to propose any reform of the industry
so her successor mary jo white be praise when she manage to get the commission to unanimously put out the two rule for comment
surely something be better than nothing
well in this case perhaps not
one proposed rule call for allow the net asset value of money market fund to fluctuate
currently fund price their share at $ 1 round to the near penny and promise they will remain there
in practice that mean that as long as the value remain at or above 99.5 cent the fund will not break the buck
the s.e.c. proposal would stretch that round out to the near hundredth of a penny
but the s.e.c. proposal would not actually do very much
fund that invest primarily in government security would not face a float net asset value
nor would so call retail money market fund which allow investor to withdraw no more than $ 1 million at a time
even those few fund that would be subject to the rule would be able to use an exist s.e.c. rule that usually let them assume market price be equal to par value for any security that will mature within 60 day
the fact that the proposal would do little have not stop the industry from complain
fund company want to change the definition of retail fund
some suggest raise the limit to $ 5 million
others say that as long as the investor have a social security number the fund should be deem retail
the other s.e.c. proposal set up an elaborate procedure that would allow but not require money market fund that have experience a lot of redemption to either impose a fee on redemption or to simply suspend such payment for 30 day
this be call the gate proposal because it erect gate to protect fund
and what be the virtue of that
well it would prevent or at least delay a run on any fund that get in trouble
if protect the fund and not its investor be the top priority maybe that make sense
but in reality it probably would do more harm than good
as eric s. rosengren the president of the federal reserve bank of boston write in a letter sign by all the other regional fed president a fund could run low on liquidity and thus initiate the gate proposal if a couple of large investor in the fund withdraw their money for any reason
that could scare investor in other fund that seem similar in some way produce more run and more gate
as this represent a new run mechanism that do not exist under the status quo the fee and gate alternative may actually increase run risk relative to not enact further reform mr. rosengren write
to much of the industry there be no problem at all
what happen in a 2008 be a once in a generation scenario that be unlikely to recur as a lawyer for one money market fund group federated investors put it in a comment letter
any further reform he add should be design to preserve the utility of money market fund 1 2 next page

in the air t. j. wilcox 's dazzle panoramic film installation at the whitney museum be an ode to new york and to film and to their mutually enhance entwining
mr. wilcox be equally enamored of both
his new work make you realize anew that the metropolis and the move image be make for each other
this piece center on an in the round bird's eye view of lower manhattan that be shoot from the artist 's studio the 18th floor penthouse of a building on union square and compress the passing of one day into 30 minute
like the old style panorama it appear on a circular screen one that be about 7 foot high and 35 foot in diameter
hang about four and a half foot above the floor it ' like a giant lampshade
in the air be something of a departure for mr. wilcox 47 who have always come across as a kind of romantic miniaturist
he be best know for film only a few minute long and often loop that be piece together from all kind of existing footage
sometimes he would reshoot the find film several time to achieve grainy fog of memory texture still image and brief tabletop sequence that he shoot himself be other staple
these work be intimate handmade reverie cryptic yet resonant with outsize theme history death love fame
mix fact and fiction they conjure historic figure like marlene dietrich or alexander the great but could also be autobiographical
while mr. wilcox 's early effort be most memorable when project small with in the air he go big and it work
he seem to have do this almost reflexively spur by the astounding 360-degree view from his studio to which he move from a low floor in the same building two year ago
paralysis be his first response to this spectacular sight
he have say more than once that he initially spend so much time look at the view that he think he may stop make art altogether
but in the end he use the beautiful implacable city as the setting and also the motivate force for a half dozen miniaturist narrative expand his collage aesthetic without sacrifice its intimacy
after considerable trial and error and some uncooperative weather mr. wilcox be finally able in july to shoot about 15 hour worth of one day in the life of new york city
it take several week for condition to align
consistent with his preference for low tech gear he downgrade his equipment from five complicated camera to the same number of relatively small rugged inexpensive gopros
he also switch from filming to shooting still which improve resolution
and he pray for sun attend by sky that be not completely cloudless and boring
he end up with 60,000 still shoot at a rate of one per second
these be individually process and then animate and speed up use a computer program that seamlessly stitch the view together eliminate distortion and even light level
the majesty and clarity of this wraparound vista be stunning
the city look old almost timeless without the detail of street traffic and storefront
the sight include the con edison clock tower zeckendorf towers freedom tower and the west side with glimpse of the hudson and new jersey
the sun appear and set cloud of many different shade and shape push their shadow across the mass of architecture airplane arrive and depart the light of the city come on and then dim as the sun return
this flat footed documentary approach evoke andy warhol 's deadpan all but motionless 1964 classic empire that eight hour stationary shot of the empire state building but mr. wilcox be too much of a storyteller to leave it at this
superimpose on the panorama be six short cameo film in a way detail that pull us from one place or era one event or personality to another across vary film method between color and black and white
the cameo appear one at a time on different part of the screen each with its own title form a carefully link loop of narrative
some draw on mr. wilcox 's life

on the horizon remember the prominent fashion illustrator antonio lopez string together image of his work and film footage and still of him and also of break dancer perform in his studio
a book of mr. lopez 's drawing and polaroids that mr. wilcox saw as a teenager ignite his desire to be in new york but by the time he arrive the scene that attract him be be ravage by aids which take mr. lopez 's life in 1987 at the age of 44

smack in the middle of the metropolitan museum there ' a nugget of compress light call medieval treasure from hildesheim
visually the show be eminently graspable a one room cluster of 50 object many jewel encrust or cover in gold
in other way the art be almost beyond reach be about the power politics of spirituality in a distant age a subject that today 's drive by museumgoer would seem to know little or care little about
a millennium ago hildesheim in northern germany be one of the ecclesiastical center of western europe
under the patronage of ottonian emperor who rule from a.d. 919 to 1014 it be a city of church the outstanding one be its grand cathedral pack with art advertising the glory of god and king
and because for both only the best would do hildesheim develop a top class art industry
its metal casting workshop be superbly innovative illuminate book pour from its scriptorium
today its church and museum still preserve one of the rich and dense concentration of 11th century european religious art anywhere
and the met show be pure cream skim off the top
that the art in it have survive at all be some kind of miracle
many of these object be make as much for active use as for contemplation
large scale sculpture be on constant public display in church be touch and kiss
small one travel the street in procession
gospel book be thumb through during service liturgical vessel be move about carry clean drop repair
and of course history keep happen
power change hand and with it control over church and treasure
in the 16th century the protestant reformation put roman catholic art under threat
enforce secularization in the 19th century also take a toll
toward the end of world war ii old hildesheim be level by bomb
a renovation of the rebuild cathedral have supply the pretext for send its art to the met
although almost none of the work can be attribute to individual artist the name of one man hover in the air that of bernward bishop of hildesheim from a.d. 993 to 1022
of noble saxon lineage he be more than a high rank cleric
he be a cosmopolitan traveler a court fixture a cultural impresario a serial self promoter and eventually a canonize saint
he be also one of the great shape art patron of his day and possibly an artist himself
his major architectural project in hildesheim be the benedictine church of st. michael for which he famously commission a set of immense bronze door each cover with narrative relief
the door do not make it to new york but at least two sculpture monumental in feeling and historically associate with bernward 's name do
one be the so call golden madonna a statue of the virgin and child carve from linden wood overlay with sheet of hammer gold
although both its figure be headless now with their light glance surface stud with gemstone they be magnetically opulent and must once have be even more so
church record report that in the 15th century the sculpture be half bury in pile of brooch ring and necklace leave as offering
more be more be the modus operandi of medieval aesthetic and the show have textbook example begin with a gospel own by bernward
the book be already nearly a century old when he acquire it but he freshen it up and make it his own by add a new cover with a byzantine ivory plaque affix to the front and his own initial splash across the back
after his death and maybe to celebrate his election to sainthood the cover be further adorn with robin' egg size crystal and miniature painting
material richness aside the golden madonna be significant for be one of the earliest fully three dimensional sculpture know from medieval europe
another be a five foot tall figure of the crucify jesus believe to have be commission by bernward for the convent of ringelheim where his sister be abbess
displayed high in the gallery it stand as a kind of benedictory centerpiece for the show
the figure apart from the arm which be 12th century replacement be cut from a single piece of wood 1 2

washington house republicans narrowly push through a bill on thursday that slash billion of dollar from the food stamp program over the objection of democrats and a veto threat from president obama
the vote set up what promise to be a major clash with the senate and dash hope for passage this year of a new five year farm bill
the vote be 217 to 210 largely along party line
republican leader under pressure from tea party back conservative say the bill be need because the food stamp program which cost nearly $ 80 billion a year have grow out of control
they say the program have expand even as jobless rate have decline with the ease recession
this bill eliminate loophole ensure work requirement and put us on a fiscally responsible path say representative marlin stutzman republican of indiana who lead effort to split the food stamp program from the overall farm bill
in the real world we measure success by result
it ' time for washington to measure success by how many family be lift out of poverty and help back on their foot not by how much washington bureaucrat spend year after year
but even with the cut the food stamp program would cost more than $ 700 billion over the next 10 year
republicans invoke former president bill clinton in their defense of the bill say that the change be in the spirit of those that he sign into law in 1996 that set work requirement for those who receive welfare
but democrats many of whom hold up picture of people they say would lose their benefit call the cut draconian and say they would plunge million into poverty
it ' a sad day in the people 's house when the leadership bring to the floor one of the most heartless bill i have ever see say representative james mcgovern democrat of massachusetts
it ' terrible policy trap in a terrible process
the measure have little chance of advance in the senate and senator debbie stabenow democrat of michigan and the chairwoman of the senate agriculture committee call it a monumental waste of time
the bill write under the direction of the house majority leader eric cantor republican of virginia would cut $ 40 billion from the food stamp program over the next 10 year
it would also require adult between 18 and 50 without minor child to find a job or to enroll in a work training program in order to receive benefit
it would also limit the time those recipient could get benefit to three month
currently state can extend food stamp benefit past three month for able bodied people who be work or prepare for work as part of a job training program
this bill make get americans back to work a priority again for our nation 's welfare program house speaker john a. boehner say
the bill would also restrict people enrol in other social welfare program from automatically become eligible for food stamp
in addition the legislation would allow state to require food stamp recipient to be test for drug and to stop lottery winner from get benefit
the senate farm bill also contain a restriction on lottery winner
critic of the measure say the cut would fall disproportionately on child
yes the federal government have budget problem but child do not cause them and cut anti hunger investment be the wrong way to solve them say bruce lesley president of first focus campaign for children a child advocacy group
accord to the congressional budget office nearly four million people would be remove from the food stamp program under the house bill start next year
the budget office say after that about three million a year would be cut off from the program
the budget office say that leave unchanged the number of food stamp recipient would decline by about 14 million people or 30 percent over the next 10 year as the economy improve
a census bureau report release on tuesday find that the program have keep about four million people above the poverty level and have prevent million more from sink further into poverty
the census data also show nearly 47 million people live in poverty close to the high level in two decade
historically the food stamp program have be part of the farm bill a huge piece of legislation that have routinely be pass every five year authorize financing for the nation 's farm and nutrition program
but in july house leader split the bill 's farm and nutrition section into separate measure pass the farm legislation over democrat objection
the move come after the house reject a propose farm bill that would have cut $ 20 billion from the food stamp program
conservative lawmaker help kill the bill say the program need deep cut

the official new york color be gray
the material be concrete and stone
that be the image
in fact new york be surprisingly green
nearly 20 percent of the city be public park land a figure that earn it second place this summer behind san diego when the trust for public land conduct its annual park score survey of the 50 large city in the united states
that ' a lot of park and the inventory be more varied than many new yorkers realize
the superstar hog the headline central park madison square the botanical garden in brooklyn and the bronx
at sidewalk level jaded urban eye scale down their expectation to the window box overflow with geranium the tub of flower outside a restaurant the cage in planting cling for dear life to the trunk of tree
however the city teem with unsung small park and garden midway on the scale between flower pot and great lawn
some be squeeze in discreet niche between building
others be new and await discovery
still others have undergo a metamorphosis
i have have my eye on a number of these gem and the waning day of summer the lull between last bloom and first frost give me an excuse to put together an eclectic tour
several of the choice come from the 52 community garden that the new york restoration project have own and manage since 1999 most of them know only to neighborhood resident
i zero in on the handful that stand out for their landscaping and design
i also include two garden in the city 's park system the bosque and the gardens of remembrance
these sanctuary develop between 2001 and 2005 have be hide in plain sight at the battery largely ignore by the throng head to the statue of liberty ellis island and governors island
the gil hodges community garden in gowanus brooklyn one of those own by the restoration project have be around for more than 30 year but it have just undergo a makeover with money from the city 's department of environmental protection and from jo malone a british fragrance company
the transform version open on wednesday
on a plot of around 3,000 square foot yvi mcevilly the restoration project 's director of design have pack in a maximum of plant activity
up front a fragrance garden send out the aroma of calycanthus daphne and other specie choose for both nose and eye appeal
a wander series of steppingstones recycled shard of concrete from the old garden lead past raise herb and vegetable bed to a birch read grove
the garden incorporate several environmentally friendly feature
a large section of it rely on rainwater collect in an underground reservoir rather than city water
on two sidewalk five rectangular tree bed have be enhance with native plant like ironweed and winterberry
one be now a bioswale a giant sponge that take in rainwater divert from the street and let it soak into a subterranean chamber thereby relieve pressure on the sewer system
small can be thrilling
it can also be elusive
the city own lentol garden in greenpoint brooklyn a sliver of green press right up against the entrance ramp to the brooklyn queens expressway offer a glimpse of enchantment
through iron gate passer by can feast their eye on plump hydrangea bloom purple and ivory butterfly bush and a magnificent chinese dogwood now display cluster of raspberrylike fruit
get inside the gate be another matter unless you be one of the high school student work on summer program in environmental science administer by the local y.m.c.a. and new york university
the restoration project 's community garden on the other hand must be open to the public 20 hour a week
sometimes the hour be post sometimes not and the local organization that operate the garden day to day do not always keep to the schedule
i never do manage to penetrate maggie 's garden a seductive beautifully landscaped enclave on 149th street near broadway in hamilton heights
even when the garden keep to their hour it can feel like a stroke of luck when the gate be open
on a recent weekend greg dava a brooklyn resident take a shortcut to the a train at high street walk into the bridge plaza community garden near the borough 's downtown area with a look of astonishment on his face
this be the first time i have ever be inside he say
i 've only see it through the gate
what he saw be one of the jewel in the community garden system
hardly big than a postage stamp it somehow manage to accommodate evergreen tree and shrub a japanese maple hydrangea and rose brick and flagstone walkway and a lily pond stock with koi
a hexagonal wooden bench encircle the garden 's ornamental cherry tree
off in one corner be a pole with brightly colored birdhouse stack atop one another add a cheery note
there be others like it scatter far and wide
curtis jackson the rapper know as 50 cent finance a renovation of a community garden in jamaica queens his old neighborhood
now name the curtis 50 cent jackson community garden it open in 2008

after tiller a new documentary by martha shane and lana wilson be a partisan document in the culture war
it could hardly be otherwise since the film 's subject abortion be one where common ground be elusive if not philosophically untenable
the four doctor interview and observe on screen who the film say be the only one in the united states openly perform third trimester abortion be heroic figure in the filmmaker eye but be condemn as murderer by those on the other side
it would be nice to believe that a movie like this could provoke civil and respectful dialogue about an intensely polarizing issue but let 's not kid ourselves
the four doctor two in new mexico one in colorado and one in nebraska honor the memory of their colleague george tiller who be assassinate in 2009 in wichita kan. where his clinic have be the scene of protest threat and attack
since that killing and especially since the 2010 election a number of state have pass more restrictive abortion law nebraska be one of them
this force dr. leroy carhart to find a new place to practice and his attempt to do so inflame anti abortion activist in iowa and in maryland where he finally open a clinic
while the other doctor warren hern in boulder and susan robinson and shelley sella who share an office in albuquerque do not face that kind of disruption they contend with continuous picketing and with the hovering invisible threat of violence
but ms. shane and ms. wilson be less interested in recapitulate political debate than in understand how the doctor approach work that would be emotionally difficult and ethically challenging even without the incessant controversy
some of the patient who come to them be in the late stage of plan pregnancy and have recently learn of catastrophic fetal anomaly
others be teenager who have through fear denial or ignorance allow their pregnancy to continue past the stage when simple more readily available abortion would be possible
in each case the physician and the counselor who work with them have to figure out an appropriate course of action
at one point dr. robinson and a colleague disagree about whether to help a young woman end her pregnancy even though she identify herself as pro life and their exchange be one of the most illuminating discussion i have see about the complicated reality of abortion
documentary can rarely be judge as work of dispassionate neutral reporting since few of them aspire to uphold those journalistic criterion
rather a documentary should be assess as a representation of the world as it be from a perspective that be itself part of that world
after tiller be impressive because it honestly present the view of supporter of legal abortion and be thus a valuable contribution to a public argument that be unlikely to end anytime soon

the brooklyn navy yard be know for its muscular collection of industrial architecture
here the battleship missouri and other warship be build and repair until the yard close five decade ago
the regular weekend tour of the navy yard cover that and more but at the end come an unexpected treat the magnificent slightly sag naval hospital a ghostly marble temple build in 1838 and empty for two decade
a new plan may sweep away the cobweb
the new york naval shipyard begin build ship in 1806 as the early republic begin to build up its navy
in 1838 one of the large structure open the 200-foot long hospital on a rise overlook the yard but now screen by tree
the architect martin e. thompson design a spare c shape building of near white marble as severe and straight as a nun 's ruler in parochial school
although two story in height the doric styling and extreme length of the front evoke the taut modernism of the international style like mies van der rohe 's flat front school of social service administration at the university of chicago
before steamship by the time sailor and marines injure in place like the halls of montezuma get back to the united states any dramatic wound would have stabilize or prove fatal so the navy probably deal with invalid rather than the freshly injure
that the hospital have a rural character be suggest by an 1851 ad in the brooklyn daily eagle for a lost red cow with a white face for which a $ 5 reward be offer for her delivery at the hospital
in 1871 the eagle report that 32 patient be in house and that although such a quiet and comfortable location may attract malingerer the sham be so easily detect that it be rare
in 1878 the eagle note an outbreak of yellow fever although at least one of the case be a false alarm cause by what the newspaper describe as an overdose of very questionable whisky and an inordinate feed of cucumber
in the spanish american war of 1898 the hospital ship solace deliver to the hospital 43 marine and sailor from the cuban campaign most suffering with disease like dysentery
one of the actual injure a rough rider name mason mitchell could hardly be accuse of malingering despite a shrapnel wound in the back he hop a ride with some reporter on their tug and go ashore in manhattan
on the other hand another trip by the solace to the hospital carry
man whose face and head be bandage others whose face be pale and sunken from long suffering man who shuffle about the deck with crutch
in december 1944 the new york times report that volunteer be visit the wound at both the navy yard hospital and the new st. albans naval hospital in queens collect christmas shopping list
the most popular request black lacy and sheer lingerie from store like b. altman and lord taylor
after the navy decommission the yard in the 1960 it hold onto the hospital for administrative headquarters
when it do leave in 1989 the navy do a conscientious seal up job and careful monitoring by the brooklyn navy yard development corporation have prevent the usual devastation
in most case an empty building in such an isolated position would be a near ruin but the plywood that cover most the window be intact the gutter and roof appear to be in good shape and there be no graffiti even the remain glaze window in the entry loggia be unbroken
it be a preservation miracle
photographer have occasionally make trip inside like richard nickel jr. who post his picture at his blog kingstonlounge
they show the entire interior completely coat with a thin coat of whitewash it look like a burial shroud
the room be empty except for some fallen plaster and peel paint like something from a stephen king novel half dream half nightmare
it be not a ruin so much as something you may run across in a haunt lose and find an architectural orphan
now the brooklyn navy yard hospital look as if it may be find
steiner studios a film and television studio be a major presence in the navy yard and plan to spend $ 400 million to take over and restore the hospital construct additional space for medium and tech purpose
douglas c. steiner the chairman say in an e mail that he first saw the hospital in 1999 and it scream movie studio to me
you can not just stroll into the navy yard except for the visitor 's center building 92 on flushing avenue which have an intriguing exhibition on its long history
that ' where two hour shuttle bus tour of the yard operate by turnstile tours leave from on saturdays and sundays
the hospital be the last stop and visitor can walk around outside but not inside
a quiet peace will wash over you as you circle the building through the overgrown grass
it ' rare in the city and unique in the navy yard otherwise a combination of hipster silicon valley high tech and ragged industrial archaeology

with its radiator and unadorned brick the small chocolate factory theater can be a stark impersonal setting
for megan v. sprenger 's flutter which have its debut on wednesday the designer brad kisicki have soften the place up a bit
a white panel float in front of the back wall and wide band of white gauze arch up the side of the room and across the ceiling
there ' a suggestion of a wedding and also of bandage
the hard fact be only partly hide
four dancer dress in white strike angular pose at the rear
they be like art object but also like a police lineup array for the audience 's inspection
gradually they advance eventually draw close enough to be touch though no one touch them
look at their viewer or at one another their eye appear to welcome contact at one moment and to shy from it the next
move independently they become distinct as individual
tara o'con seem the most at ease with herself please by a secret bend her compact form claim space in spiral
michael ingle be big gentle slow to reveal his more compelling oddity and drive
anna adams stark be unruly awkward defensive with an uplift chin
donna cicchesi be a seductress in body language but beneath her bang her eye keep retreat to the side
she tend to stay out of everyone else 's way
much of the time each performer do his or her own thing all at once but the interaction among them take on drama
the work be highly episodic a structure emphasize by joe levasseur 's lighting subtly cool and warm and by jason sebastian 's sound design shift among buzz guitar figure and sometimes a beat
though all four dancer occasionally come together in stillness or in burst of motion the most intense encounter occur in pair
two people build some pattern in common until one of them break off
two people almost touch but keep a tiny distance or they do touch and the touch turn violent
someone come away smug someone come away hurt
play against more abstract element the interpersonal drama intrigue
the work be skillfully shape and pace
yet despite its compositional sophistication there ' something adolescent about it all something high school like a white on white abstraction of the breakfast club
the identify mannerism like ms. cicchesi 's tentative raising of her hand as in class grow irritating with repetition
what at first seem to reveal character eventually become a wall
that happen in life too but as art i find it dispiriting
the dancer leave the space one by one alone
i wish i have be more sorry to see them go

candace pert a neuroscientist who help discover a fundamental element of brain chemistry as a graduate student and go on to become a major proponent of alternative medicine die on sept. 12 at her home in potomac md.
she be 67
the cause be cardiac arrest say her sister deane beebe
dr. pert be work at the johns hopkins university school of medicine in the 1970 when a team she be on find one of the most seek after object in brain research the receptor in the brain that opiate like morphine fit into like a key in a lock allow the drug 's effect to work
the discovery of the opioid receptor would in 1978 earn the covet albert lasker award often a precursor to the nobel prize
the award go to solomon h. snyder who head the lab
neither dr. pert nor any of the other lab assistant be cite
such omission be common in the world of science the graduate student in the lab rarely get credit beyond be the first name on the paper describe the research
but dr. pert do something unusual she protest send a letter to the head of the foundation that award the prize say she have play a key role in initiate the research and follow it up and be angry and upset to be exclude
her letter cause a sensation in the field
some saw her exclusion as an example of the burden and barrier woman face in science career
in a 1979 article about dr. pert in the the washington post dr. snyder who have laud dr. pert 's contribution in his lasker acceptance speech argue that that ' the way the game be play add that today 's graduate student will be tomorrow 's lab chief and that when they have student it will be the same
the two later reconcile
in an e mail interview on wednesday dr. snyder now a professor in the solomon h. snyder department of neuroscience at johns hopkins call dr. pert one of the most creative innovative graduate student i have ever mentor
dr. pert continue her career at the national institute of mental health where she continue to do pioneering work on receptor and the peptide that correspond to them come to conclusion that steer her toward alternative medicine
she become a lead proponent of the unity of mind and body and the ability of emotion to affect health
when bill moyers in a 1993 pbs special healing and the mind ask her be you say that the mind talk to the body so to speak through these neuropeptides
she answer why be you make the mind outside of the body
she be also feature prominently in the 2004 film what the $
do we know which attempt to bridge science and spirituality
in her best know book molecules of emotion the science behind mind body medicine publish in 1997 dr. pert advocate a more holistic approach to understand health
i 've come to believe that virtually all illness if not psychosomatic in foundation have a definite psychosomatic component she write
the molecule of emotion she argue run every system in our body create a bodymind 's intelligence that be wise enough to seek wellness without a great deal of high tech medical intervention
the author deepak chopra who write the foreword to molecules of emotion call the book a landmark in our understanding of the mind body connection
dr. miles herkenham a former colleague at the national institute of mental health say that it may seem odd to an outside observer that a scientist of dr. pert 's training would go into what he call the squishy world of alternative medicine
but the common theme that underlie all of her work be her knowledge as a pharmacologist of ligand peptide and how they work through receptor he say add she follow her own passion
her work lead dr. pert to team up with her husband dr. michael ruff an immunologist to investigate another protein peptide t. they hop that it would be effective in fight h.i.v. by block the entry of the virus into cell
while the drug show promise it have not lead to a successful treatment
dr. pert publish more than 250 scientific paper on peptide
in more recent year she and dr. ruff found a company rapid pharmaceuticals that be develop peptide base drug to treat alzheimer 's cardiovascular disease and other disease by fight the inflammation that underlie many chronic medical condition

he grow traited or biotech corn and soy on some 1,500 acre and estimate that his yield would fall by 20 percent if he switch to conventional crop and stop use glyphosate know by brand name like roundup and buccaneer

but they 're go to have to show me that conventional genetics can produce the same income
the local difference over glyphosate be feed the long run debate over biotech crop which currently account for roughly 90 percent of the corn soybean and sugar beet grow in the united states
while regulator and many scientist say biotech crop be no different from their conventional cousin others worry that they be damage the environment and human health
the battle be be wag at the poll with ballot initiative to require labeling of genetically modify food in courtroom where lawyer want to undo patent on biotech seed and on supermarket shelf contain product promote conventionally grow ingredient
now some farmer be take a close look at their soil
first patent by monsanto as a herbicide in 1974 glyphosate have help revolutionize farming by make it easy and cheap to grow crop
the use of the herbicide have grow exponentially along with biotech crop
the pervasive use though be prompt some concern
critic point in part to the rise of so call superweeds which be more resistant to the herbicide
to fight them farmer sometimes have to spray the toxic herbicide two to three time during the grow season
then there be the feel of the soil
dirt in two field around alton where biotech corn be be grow be hard and compact
pry corn stalk from the soil with a shovel be difficult and when the plant finally come up their root be trap in a chunk of dirt
once free the root spread out flat like a fan and be stud with only a few nodule which be critical to the exchange of nutrient
in comparison conventional corn in adjacent field could be tug from the ground by hand and dirt with the consistency of wet coffee ground fall off the corn plant knobby root
because glyphosate move into the soil from the plant it seem to affect the rhizosphere the ecology around the root zone which in turn can affect plant health say robert kremer a scientist at the united states agriculture department who have study the impact of glyphosate on soybean for more than a decade and have warn of the herbicide 's impact on soil health
like the human microbiome the plant root system rely on a complex system of bacteria fungi and mineral in the soil
the combination in the right balance help protect the crop from disease and improve photosynthesis
in some study scientist have find that a big selling point for the pesticide that it bind tightly to mineral in the soil like calcium boron and manganese thus prevent runoff also mean it compete with plant for those nutrient
other research indicate that glyphosate can alter the mix of bacteria and fungi that interact with plant root system make them more susceptible to parasite and pathogen
antibiotic kill bacteria or reduce their growth but some of those bacteria be useful say verlyn sneller president of verity a small company that sell sugar base fertilizer and water system and work to persuade farmer like mr. vermeer to switch to conventional crop
but research detail the adverse effect with glyphosate be limited and other study counter such finding
monsanto which sell roundup and seed resistant to glyphosate say there be no credible evidence that the herbicide cause extend adverse effect to microbial process in soil
a team of scientist from the agriculture department similarly review much of the research and find the herbicide to be fairly benign

the rule on new power plant will soon face a 60-day public comment period likely to be follow by intensive industry and environmental lobbying and possible court challenge
official say the rule could be finalize by the fall of 2014
once the rule be in place coal power plant would be require to limit their emission likely by instal technology call carbon capture and sequestration which scrub carbon dioxide from their emission before they reach the plant smokestack
the technology then pump it into permanent storage underground
industry representative argue that such technology have not be prove on a large scale and would be extraordinarily expensive and therefore in violation of provision in the clean air act that require the regulation to be adequately demonstrate and not exorbitant in cost
i think the agency have real problem meet both of those standard mr. segal say

because the cost of borrow for bank to make additional loan be essentially the interest rate on the marginal standing facility that rate tend to have a great effect on the interest rate that bank charge customer for loan
the reduction of the marginal standing facility by 0.75 percentage point be encouraging as this be work as the short term interest rate say chandrajit banerjee director general of the confederation of indian industry

the marina bay temporary street circuit on which the singapore grand prix run this weekend be the second slow track of the season after monaco with an average speed of 172 kilometer per hour and an average cornering speed of 105 k.p.h
with its 23 corner extreme heat and humidity and night run singapore 's 106.8-mile race be one of the season 's hardest on the car brake tire and driver leave no part of the setup unpunished
it ' a bumpy track and because it be use just once a year for the grand prix the grip change throughout the weekend as it collect rubber from both the elite competitor car and those of the support race
that mean that the team must spend the entire weekend try to deal with the continually move target of the best car setup
ten of the corner be in the final sector of the track driver change gear more than 5,000 time during the race and at more than 100 second the lap time be the long of the year
in fact with its 61 lap the race have either reach the official two hour limit as it do last year or go to within five minute of the limit every year since the first singapore grand prix in 2008
approximately 46 percent of the lap be take at full throttle compare with more than 75 percent at the previous race at the high speed low downforce track in monza italy
singapore 's twisty layout be hard on brake and with all the gear change on the gearbox
the marina bay circuit have a low average speed due to the high amount of corner say remi taffin the head of the renault engine provider 's track operation
so the emphasis be on give the driver driveability through the low rev range between 8,000 r.p.m and
13,000 r.p.m
and a responsive engine on the short link between the right angle turn he say
engine map need to give good traction so this be a race we will work particularly closely with the chassis engineer to get a neutral set up
pirelli will provide the team its medium and supersoft tire
the tight and twisty corner make the supersoft version not use since the canadian grand prix in june the right tire to generate traction and grip while the medium tire contribute extra durability
the second half of the season start off with two of the fast and most demanding race for tire of the year in belgium and italy say paul hembery the director of the pirelli tire motor sport program
singapore be a completely different challenge the final street race of the season which be ideal territory for the supersoft tire he add
as always our selection have concentrate on provide the best opportunity for strategy as well as the most effective race tire
because it be a long race the car carry one of the heavy fuel load of the year
that put a lot more energy into the tire at the start of the race require particular attention to manage the first stint
one of the big cause of tire wear however be wheel spin
so the rear suspension must be set up to give maximum longitudinal grip
unusual for a street race singapore be hot and humid with high speed heavy braking area and so many corner
the tire have to perform well under traction and braking
the only relief for the tire be that because it be a night race the track temperature drop from a high of around 50 degree celsius 122 degree fahrenheit in the day to around 30 degree celsius 86 degree fahrenheit during the race
but that still make for a hot and humid race one of the tough of the season
twenty percent of the lap be do on braking and 45 percent at full throttle
driver undergo 2.5g 's for three second at turn 22
all the corner be generally take in second or third gear so you 're try to find the best setup compromise say jenson button a driver at the mclaren mercedes team particularly as you need good end of straight speed for overtake into turn 7
because it be a bumpy circuit the setup must favor the mechanical over the aerodynamic
but its slow twisty nature also require maximum downforce on both the front and rear wing
the many high curb require good suspension compliance and the frequent braking require the car to be set up soft
brake cooling like engine cooling be difficult not so much because of hard braking but because of frequent braking throughout the whole lap
the wear and tear be on all part of the brake disc pad and caliper
to help cool the engine the car 's bodywork must often be open in various place
formula one have always be an innovative force in technology for road car as the sport 's team seek quick reliable solution to create better faster car in an environment that be more competitive and evolve fast than that of the consumer car industry
in recent year however as the series have move away from purely mechanical to electronic system in the race car in the pit lane garage and the whole team environment of a race innovation from the series have expand far beyond the realm of the automobile
they now extend into many other aspect of daily life from train the military and hospital operating room staff use pit stop tactic to design watch and luggage with formula one car material and technique
one of the most advanced extension of the lesson learn through the harsh competitive environment of a formula one race be now help to create a future that will touch on just about every aspect of life
know as the internet of thing it have to do with the electronic connectivity of our everyday life and the vast network that have already begin to connect everything from our car to the road to our home and hospital and even agriculture with the smart cow with biometric monitoring and analysis watch grazing rotation and milk solid data analysis
the mclaren formula one team have even connect sick baby with their telemetry system in a hospital in britain to provide early warning of ailment like a heart attack
in fact no other team of the sport 's elite racing team be as deeply involve in the study of improve the internet of thing as be the mclaren team through its sister company mclaren electronic systems
the company which be base in britain provide the engine control unit or ecu to all of the other formula one team and since last year to the nascar team in the u.s.-based auto racing series
an ecu be the electronic brain of a race car that control the engine to ensure optimal performance
it also send data back to the team garage and the team factory and that be one of the link to the internet of thing
the internet of thing consist of the billion of connection a kind of universal global neural network in the computing cloud that be expect to make almost every aspect of our life connect in the future
mclaren 's racing environment be branch out into the large world via its work with the freescale semiconductor company of austin texas which consider itself the internet of thing company
freescale provide the computer chip that be the brain and channel of this electronic equipment
in a report on the internet of thing by kaivan karimi a director of freescale semiconductor and gary atkinson a director at arm a british semiconductor and software company the author use one of the most common example to illustrate the functioning of the internet of thing a toaster
your old toaster that mechanically control the color of your toast now have an mcu a micro controller in it and the mcu control the color of your toast the author write
the toaster complete its task more consistently and reliably and because it be now a smart toaster it have the ability to communicate with you electronically use its touchpad or switch
after a device become smart through the integration of embed processing the next logical step be remote communication with the smart device to help make life easy they add

for example if i be run late at the office can i turn on my house light for security reason use my laptop or mobile phone
that be precisely where the connection to formula one and the ecu and other electronic sensor and telemetry of a formula one car come into play

â bernie ecclestone 82 be president and chief executive of formula one management and formula one administration which own and operate the formula one racing series

in 1904 the cooper underwear company run a magazine ad announce a new product for bachelor
in the before photo a man avert his eye from the camera as if embarrassed he have lose all the button on his undershirt and have safety pin its flap together
in the after photo a virile gentleman sport a handlebar mustache smoke a cigar and wear a bachelor undershirt stretchy enough to be pull over the head
no safety pin no button no needle no thread run the slogan aim at man with no wife and no sewing skill
someone in the u.s. navy must have see the logic in this because the following year the quartermaster 's office specify that sailor should wear undershirt with no button under their uniform soon thousand of man become acquaint with the comfort of the cotton pullover
though the cooper underwear company popularize the crew neck shirt they do not invent the style
the shirt evolve out of the long john that man wear in the 19th century when a number of garment maker experiment with method that would allow the fabric to stretch over the head and then snap back into shape
in the 1890 the cotton pullover still look like underwear to most people and wear it in public be consider scandalous
lawmaker in havana go so far as to ban the public display of any underwearlike top and so laborer have to toil in the heat wear long sleeve shirt with button
but gradually the crew neck catch on
in 1920 the garment be reborn under another name thanks partly to f. scott fitzgerald
accord to the oxford english dictionary the author be the first to use the word t shirt in print it appear in the novel this side of paradise in a list of accouterment that a character carry with him to board school
fitzgerald seem to have assume that the idea of a t shirt so name presumably because of the shirt 's shape would be familiar to reader and that they would associate it with the white flannel bareheaded youth of new england prep school
by the 1940 t shirt have become ubiquitous in high school
a newspaper columnist name nancy pepper write that teenager own closet full of t shirt and customize them with sew on patch and fringe
she report that some high school boy even use their t shirt to advertise that they be available for make out session around the neckline of their shirt the boy inscribe the word neck here

dip into the comment the american text genre of the moment and you can sense the current that move american life
the comment be where the real america be someone once write in a comment thread
comment also may be the most obnoxious development of the web the wild back alley where people sound their acid yawps
their tenor be now so bad that last november a game designer shane liesegang set up a twitter feed @avoidcomment where he tweet thing like i once show a comment section to a man in reno just to watch him cry
he now have 27,000 follower
when we complain about comment i have notice we do so as if we 're deal with some emanation of human nature or the lusty democratic energy of the american soul
but when i go dig into the history of the web to find out where online comment really come from it ' clear that they 're the consequence of what be technically feasible at a certain point and how that feasibility be subsequently implement
we tend to think that comment represent the culture but in fact the distinct culture of comment grow out of digital constraint
give what web user have to work with comment be bind to get weedy
comment as we know them line of text stack atop one another in chronological order be direct descendant of bulletin board system or b.b.s. which date to the 1970 user could dial in with a modem and contribute to discussion forum
the computer code that determine the order in which text appear on a b.b.s. also provide the basic architecture of the comment thread
that code or script become the basis for an early commenting function call the guest book a place for simple text entry in which any visitor could type a note
guest book be attach to the web site as a whole not to any specific content on it
this create confusion about the sort of opportunity that the guest book present
be it the soapbox of the online world
or be it a bathroom wall
fray.com a popular web site start in 1996 which use freeware guest book script be among the first to harness the potential of the guest book
a question would be pose and answer contribute by reader would be publish in real time
the web site be essentially a collection of guest book each one with a prompt and the reply be all stand alone contribution adrift in a sea of other people who be speak to themselves
it ' difficult to give credit for the invention of comment as we now understand them to one specific person or site
an interactive book travel with samantha which allow reader to submit comment via a form much as modern comment be win a best of the web award for document design in 1994 which be the same year that a consortium of world wide web developer create w3 interactive talk to discuss technical matter on which discussion point be submit by a form that make them part of a topic page

for the past 12 year since his laud esther story peter orner have be engage in a strange quiet and wonderful experiment
he have write four work of fiction two novel and two story collection all compose of canny snippet that build with subtle accumulative power to create book autobiographical in feel if not necessarily in fact
in all but his first novel the second coming of mavala shikongo the book return to the same character from startle vantage point orner be write in spiral move restlessly out to embody imagine character but always return to the chicago and fall river mass. family of his most frequent first person narrator a young man who be roughly his age
in each of his book orner 's crystalline sentence and his ability to pay close and sustain attention to small moment transform the ordinary element of each story into an even more astonishing whole
last car over the sagamore bridge orner 's new collection be compose of 52 story most no longer than a few page
there be many strand run through the weave of this book one be a series feature the above mention family another be a group of italicize first person story another imagines people outside of the central character/narrator 's experience like a woman who sell television antenna in a mexico city plaza and a serbian woman sit in a coffee shop
yet another strand observe famous people mary todd lincoln richard j. daley ted kennedy geraldo rivera and isaac babel one of many writer with whom orner be in conversation
chekhov be another clear influence as be the evan s. connell of mr. bridge and mrs. bridge novel write in the same episodic manner orner favor
at his strong orner can nail interior monologue in a way that recall grace paley
just listen to the voice of walt kaplan a character who also appear in esther story and in the novel love and shame and love would my head be a head of lettuce
i drive the last car over the sagamore bridge before the state police close it off
the cape cod canal all atempest beneath
no car come no car go
the bridge cable flap like rubber band
you think in certain circumstance a few thousand foot of bridge be not a thousand mile
a writer who keep return to the same subject run a big risk
the reader can feel like an invisible observer in a room wall with mirror watch the author fascinate by the endless reflection of himself
just when you think he ' finish examine this interesting feature here it be again from a different angle
when orner return too often to the same beat or idea he can almost reverse the effect of his true gift which be the ability to take element we have see before the historical character the suburb the tight knit jewish family chicago and by the force of his fascination make them thrillingly strange
this talent never fail orner yet when he look too often at the same loss or character or mood he teeter on the verge of return the strange back to the familiar
where would we be though without writer who take great risk
they be the interesting one to follow from book to book
sometimes the risky writer stumble in his funambulist guise and you wonder if he ' about to dive into the drink
in last car over the sagamore bridge orner be especially daring with structure
though the collection be organize into four loose section base on what i interpret as loss murder longing and what remain after loss it ' difficult to understand why these story have to appear in the same book
the leap from historical character to internal narrative to apparent transcription make a reader a little dizzy
most great story collection jesus son by denis johnson twilight of the superheroes by deborah eisenberg variety of disturbance by lydia davis contain story that feel as if they must be together through character thematic refraction or just a barely detectable urgency
they develop subtle argument from beginning to end
though every story in last car over the sagamore bridge be excellent incisive move
the collection as a whole never quite coheres there be 52 passionate argument be make in the 52 story but a person come to orner for the first time may feel that each story be mostly argue with itself
luckily there be other way of read story collection than in a single linear sweep
a reader could dip into this book anywhere go for a walk and come back later to be move differently
or a reader could and perhaps should also read the collection as an integral part of a much great whole one still expand and contracting and coiling inward a living and breathing project that be evolve in a way that uncannily mimic memory or life itself

lynda barry be a writer cartoonist and assistant professor of interdisciplinary creativity at the university of wisconsin madison
in the national consciousness harlem have usually be define by two era the artistic and cultural explosion of the 1920s know as the harlem renaissance and the drug fuel devastation that begin in the 1950 and peak in the late 80
the harlem renaissance have be well document by its poet novelist and essayist as well as by a legion of scholar in the decade since
the long depressing ghetto year be recount most eloquently by james baldwin and by less mortal like sociologist memoirists politician hollywood screenwriter and rapper
today 's white harlem of multimillion-â­dollar brownstone and flashy eatery be already the subject of book blog and innumerable magazine travel article
in her book harlem nocturne women artists and progressive politics during world war ii farah jasmine griffin a professor at columbia university delve into a largely underexplored aspect of harlem 's rich history the year just before during and immediately after world war ii a period of optimism creativity and turmoil
moreover griffin use the life of three female artist the choreographer and dancer pearl primus the writer ann petry and the composer and pianist mary lou williams as signpost through an era in a work that paint the great generation in a much less flattering light than do the usual jingoistic account
griffin 's narrative encompass the war and the second great migration of black to the north from the south
she also highlight two movement that will be less familiar to contemporary reader the double v or double victory campaign in which black americans fight
overseas for their country but also to be recognize as citizen at home and the popular front initiative conceive by the communist party in response to the economic crisis of the great depression and the rise of fascism
for black people griffin write of double v the war provide an opportunity to accelerate their demand for equality

black americans highlight the distance between this ideal of america and the reality of ongoing racial inequality often through the black press and civil right organization
the popular front meanwhile focus on culture as an especially important forum for educate and mobilize audience in support of an antifascist agenda
although by 1939 its official end have come the idea of it would continue throughout the war year
without popular front venue like cafe society or publication such as pm a leftist newspaper it be doubtful that petry primus and williams could have meet with such success
griffin argue that her three main subject consistently confront the darkness of our nation 's soul
they be critical of white supremacy and the excess of american capitalism
yet their art and their activism also denote a firm belief in the transformative nature of social change
none of these woman be native new yorkers
