when it come to ratatouille there be no shortage of recipe
there ' the traditional time consume kind in which you saute all the vegetable separately then stew them together slowly in a casserole
there ' the shortcut method of simmer everything at once
there ' roast ratatouille microwave ratatouille and even steamed ratatouille though that one do not tempt me at all
finally there ' grill ratatouille a recipe with many charm both in the method and the result
grilling take the whole process outside allow you to enjoy the last handful of temperate night
the grill also add a lovely smoky nuance to the finished dish without overpower the essential flavor of vegetable olive oil and herb
and grill ratatouille be relatively fast to make maybe not as quick as use the microwave but tasty
all of this say grill vegetable for a ratatouille do take some finesse
the first time i try i do everything wrong
i build a very hot very high fire coat the pepper zucchini and eggplant in olive oil then plop them onto the grill only to watch my poor vegetable blaze up and burn
so the next time i take thing more slowly
i build a less intense fire and spread out the coal more evenly
i leave off the oil at least while the vegetable cook
then i hang around them sip wine and keep an eye on their various state of doneness pull off each piece as soon as it be char in spot and very tender
no one want al dente ratatouille
once everything be thoroughly cook and slightly cool i chop up the vegetable and douse them in olive oil which be as essential to good ratatouille as the eggplant and pepper
i also stir in copious amount of basil and garlic
what i get be something less stew y and more salad like than a typical ratatouille but with a concentrated flavor and velvety texture along with a garlicky kick
i serve it with herbed goat cheese and crisp toast while it be still warm then eat the cold leftover the next day with a dollop of yogurt and a sprinkle of chile powder
like the original it will keep for many day in the fridge get better as it sit
grill ratatouille may not replace the other ratatouille variation in your repertory
but it ' a nice deeply flavored addition to the list

sadness be an emotion we usually try to avoid
so why do we choose to listen to sad music
musicologist and philosopher have wonder about this
sad music can induce intense emotion yet the type of sadness evoke by music also seem pleasing in its own way
why
aristotle famously suggest the idea of catharsis that by overwhelm us with an undesirable emotion music or drama somehow purge us of it
but what if despite their apparent similarity sadness in the realm of artistic appreciation be not the same thing as sadness in everyday life
in a study publish this summer in the journal frontiers in psychology my colleague and i explore the idea that musical emotion encompass both the feel emotion that the music induce in the listener and the perceive emotion that the listener judge the music to express
by isolate these two overlap set of emotion and observe how they relate to each other we hop to gain a better understanding of sad music
forty four people serve as participant in our experiment
we ask them to listen to one of three musical excerpt of approximately 30 second each
the excerpt be from mikhail glinka 's la separation f minor felix blumenfeld 's sur mer g minor and enrique granados 's allegro de concierto c sharp major though the excerpt be in g major which we transpose to g minor
we be interested in the minor key because it be canonically associate with sad music and we steer clear of well know composition to avoid interference from any personal memory relate to the piece
our participant be more or less split between man and woman as well as between musician and nonmusicians though these division turn out to be immaterial to our finding
a participant would listen to an excerpt and then answer a question about his feel emotion how do you feel when listen to this music
then he would listen to a happy version of the excerpt i.e. transpose into the major key and answer the same question
next he would listen to the excerpt again in both sad and happy version each time answer a question about other listener that be design to elicit perceived emotion how would normal people feel when listen to this music
this be a slight simplification in the actual study the order in which the participant answer question about felt and perceive emotion and listen to sad and happy excerpt vary from participant to participant
our participant answer each question by rat 62 emotion relate descriptive word and phrase from happy to sad from bouncy to solemn from heroic to wistful on a scale from 0 not at all to 4 very much
we find as anticipate that feel emotion do not correspond exactly to perceive emotion
although the sad music be both perceive and feel as tragic e.g. gloomy meditative and miserable the listener do not actually feel the tragic emotion as much as they perceive it
likewise when listen to sad music the listener feel more romantic emotion e.g. fascinated dear and in love and blithe emotion e.g. merry animated and feel like dance than they perceive
something similar happen with the happy music perceive blithe emotion be rat high than their felt counterpart
in general it appear that perceive emotion may be rat high than feel emotion when it come to emotional category characteristically associate with a give key
when listen to sad music then there be a tension or slippage between the two type of emotion
how be we to understand this gap
one answer may be that in everyday life we typically experience emotion that have a direct connection to whatever object or situation give rise to them
but when we listen to sad music or watch a sad movie or read a sad novel we be inoculate from any real threat or danger that the music or movie or novel represent
if this be true what we experience when we listen to sad music may be think of as vicarious emotion
here there be no object or situation that induce emotion directly as in regular life
instead the vicarious emotion be free from the essential unpleasantness of their genuine counterpart while still draw force from the similarity between the two
we need to study vicarious emotion further
in do so we may be able to improve our understanding of a neglect feature of our emotional system namely its sensitivity to something other than palpable need or threat
when we weep at the beauty of sad music we experience a profound aspect of our emotional self that may contain insight about the meaning and significance of artistic experience and also about ourselves as human being
ai kawakami be a postdoctoral fellow with the okanoya emotional information project of the japan science and technology agency

new york tough new limit on the amount of heat trap emission new power plant can emit will likely accelerate a shift away from coal fire power and toward electricity generate with natural ga wind and sunshine
power price for home business and factory may eventually rise and nuclear power could return to fashion
the rule propose by the obama administration friday will have little effect on the mix of power source and electricity price anytime soon because it only apply to new power plant and be likely to be challenge in court
even so market force be already reshape power market in the same way the rule will
a boom in natural ga production in the u.s. have dramatically increase supply send price plummet and prompt a shift away from coal
the rule require new coal plant to be build with extremely expensive equipment to reduce carbon dioxide emission
that will make coal look prohibitively expensive to regulator and utility plan for the future
by comparison natural ga fire plant which emit half as much carbon dioxide as coal plant along with wind turbine and solar panel will look like a bargain
jason bordoff director of columbia university 's center on global energy policy call the rule consistent with already evolve market trend toward the use of natural ga instead of coal and describe it as cost effective
nonetheless it create financial winner and loser
here ' how the landscape could change for company and customer
winners natural ga
most new natural ga fire power plant will stay within the rule 's emission limit without require new equipment
that mean natural ga fire plant already by far the cheap power plant to build and operate will likely remain the top choice for utility
as utility rely more on natural ga to generate electricity demand for the fuel will increase and price could rise
that would mean more revenue for domestic natural ga drillers such as exxonmobil and chesapeake energy drilling service company such as halliburton and baker hughes and pipeline company such as spectra energy and kinder morgan
it will also help maker of natural ga fire turbine such as general electric and siemens
renewable energy
wind and solar developer such as nextera energy and firstsolar may see increase demand for large project especially if power price rise
that would also help rooftop solar installers such as solar city attract more interest from home and business
nuclear power
nuclear like coal have suffer from the low power price bring on by cheap natural ga
utility have abandon ambitious plan to build new nuclear plant and they have shut down age plant that have become too expensive to run
if price rise nuclear operator such as exelon and entergy will benefit
and because the new rule make new coal plant so expensive utility afraid of rely too heavily on natural ga for future power production may turn instead to nuclear
power generator
if electricity price rise as coal use decline company that sell wholesale electric power such nrg energy and calpine may benefit
losers coal miner
the u.s. coal industry be already struggle because coal supply pile up and price drop as natural ga gain favor
u.s. production be expect to fall to a 20-year low this year and 151 mine that employ 2,658 worker be idle in the first half of this year accord to snl energy
while coal will continue to be an important fuel for electricity generation in the u.s. for decade it appear to be face a long slow decline
the country will get less and less coal from the comparatively high cost appalachian region and more from cheap to access coal deposit in the illinois basin and in wyoming
company with large appalachian operation such as james river coal and alpha natural resources will likely continue to suffer
electric customer
natural ga price generally dictate the price of all electricity in the u.s.
if demand for natural ga rise fast than drillers supply it the price will rise and drag power price up too possibly boost electric bill for home and business
in the past natural ga price have be extraordinarily volatile
industrial company who have use low power price in the u.s. as a competitive advantage be concern
the national association of manufacturers say in a statement friday that the rule will hurt competitiveness and job creation

when you can drive a car off the lot with that new car smell for a mere $ 199- or $ 299-a month lease many consumer can not help ask how can i afford not to take this deal
after all if your family be already pay for cable television and a couple of cellphone many of the current lease be offer may seem like a relative steal
and with lease fuel surprisingly strong car sale it seem that more driver be think in those term
indeed the pay as you go smartphone mentality seem to have seep into the car market especially with young buyer many of whom do not seem to mind that they do not own anything at the end of the lease 's term
but that have not change the long term economics of leasing it still cost several thousand dollar more than buy a new car not to mention a newish use car
people 's attitude be shift say philip reed senior consumer advice editor at edmunds.com
the car be be see more as a commodity to be use and then return
ownership be a big part of the world war ii generation people want to own their house and own their car
they be teach that be financially responsible
there be reason certain people may want to lease the first one be you have extra money to burn
but for the rest of us the financial consequence be worth re examining especially when you have a slew of compete financial priority like college tuition retirement or even a nice vacation
so let 's start with the hard number
mr. reed look at three way you could acquire a four door honda accord ex buy a new 2014 model lease the same 2014 car or buy a used 2011 accord with 36,000 mile
many people in the new york area be pay about $ 28,211 for the new car include tax title and registration
the analysis look at the cost over six year since the average person own a car for that long and it incorporate typical buying pattern the new accord be purchase with a five year loan the use car be finance with a four year loan and the person who be lease must take out two consecutive 36-month lease
the rest of the assumption be detail on the accompanying chart
lease initially seem to be the cheap route when you look at total out of pocket expense it cost $ 5,244 less than buy new
buy a used car be still the most economical
you save $ 5,277 compare with leasing and it ' about a whopping $ 10,500 less than buy new
but when you account for the teensy fact that you do not own anything at the end of those six year the calculus change
if you have buy the car new it would still be worth about $ 11,000 accord to edmunds.com 's calculator
the used accord would be worth around $ 5,000
so after you factor in that equity leasing cost $ 5,756 more than buy a new car and $ 10,277 more than buy use
buy new cost $ 4,521 more than buy use
leasing be the loser across the board
if you ask me what be the most expensive way to get a car the answer would be you only want to own it during its period of great depreciation and then move to another new vehicle say jeff bartlett deputy automotive editor at consumer reports
well that ' what leasing be
with that analysis in mind here be some other factor that need to be consider when decide the best way to acquire a car
needs versus want be there anything you absolutely need now that you can not get in a lightly use car that ' only a few year old
some expert say you can make a decent argument for new car base on some recent safety improvement
the insurance institute for highway safety which some expert say tend to have more rigorous guideline than the government add new recommendation after its late small frontal crash test last summer
and some manufacturer have be update their exist model mr. bartlett say to meet those standard
though it ' hard to argue that anyone need to have the late technology that have come a long way in the last couple of year too
that two- to three year time difference mean the world in term of connectivity mr. bartlett add
now there be stereo in mainstream car that offer pandora aha and stitcher for stream internet radio via a smartphone and allow you to control an ipod
plus usb connection be fast replace traditional microplugs and bluetooth be near ubiquitous
the expectation of mobile connectivity and what you can do on the run have change dramatically
leasing
it become a difficult cycle to escape
unless you save extra money while leasing you may not have accumulate enough for a down payment on your next car and you wo not have a car to trade in
and now that you 're accustomed to the low monthly payment it will be hard to stomach the much high monthly cost of buy new or even a not too old used car in some case
you will avoid repair or maintenance cost except for oil change and tire rotation that use and even new car buyer would eventually have to pay
but you will probably pay more for insurance with a lease vehicle which mr. reed say be almost as much as the extra maintenance
it end up be close to a wash
leasing also allow you to get into a car right away with little financial disruption it require little or no money down and minimal outlay each month
there ' also the fact that you 're drive a brand new car with all of the late technological and safety feature
time horizon
beyond the number your time horizon should also help determine what you ultimately decide
if you be someone who know they be go to own a car for 10 year and you be drive all over the country you be not the type of person who should be leasing say alec gutierrez a senior market analyst of automotive insight at kelley blue book refer to the mileage limit of about 12,000 a year on lease vehicle
if you go beyond that you be likely to be hit with significant penalty
besides buy a new car and hold onto it be more economical now
you be make pretty high payment for about four or five year but the dependability of car be really great these day say mr. reed
it can probably go another five year with minimal cost
lease mechanics
you 're essentially pay for the amount of value the car lose over the course of your lease in other word the price you pay be base on the vehicle 's residual value at the end of the term
consider a $ 30,000 car that be worth $ 15,000 after three year
you will divide that into monthly payment and that be your lease payment plus interest and some fee mr. reed explain
you also only pay sale tax on the amount of the vehicle that you use in this case $ 15,000
that ' why car that retain their value tend to translate into better deal for leasing the high the residual value the low the monthly payment
thing like mercedes bmw and honda hold their value very well and make very good lease car mr. reed say
if you do lease figure out the number of mile you want to drive each year how long a lease you want and how much you want to put down
then call a few different dealer and ask them to quote you a monthly payment
this be the simple way to shop around mr. reed say though leasing aficionado may choose to get more technical
buying used
if you buy used you may need to come up with a large down payment than if you buy new since more people tend to default on used car you may have to put 10 to 20 percent down on a used car compare with 0 to 10 percent for a new one
but because of the easily repossessed nature of the collateral if there be one loan that be easy to qualify for it tend to be a car loan say greg mcbride senior financial analyst at bankrate.com
pay cash
of course there ' always the option of pay for a car the old fashioned way save up and pay cash
that ' what mr. bartlett of consumer reports do whether he be buy new or use
obviously nobody do this he say
but when you pay cash you do not have to worry about them sneak in all of these fee
you just negotiate a price and then write a check for that number
if i can put some of it on my credit card and then get the point and pay it off at the end of the month i come out ahead

what be it about a bread and fry slice of meat that be so cross culturally endearing
call it a cutlet call it chicken fry steak
call it schnitzel or milanesa or cotoletta alla milanese everybody love it the world around
use beef veal or pork
or use chicken or turkey
it ' all good
the technique be always the same the meat be flatten by pound dip in flour and beat egg then coat in bread crumb and shallow fried until golden and crisp
there be abundant regional variation and i try to sample them wherever i go
quality varies but if you be a fan it be hard to find a truly bad version
the point be even a tough cut of meat when prepare in this fashion emerge from the pan succulent and tender
i have have genuine delicate wiener schnitzel in vienna authentic big as a plate milanese cutlet in milan and the well love milanesa in argentina sometimes as a sandwich
i can not resist even a so so truck stop rendition of chicken fry anything country gravy and all
i have a fondness for my israeli friend 's stellar chicken schnitzel roll in cornflake crumb
and a morsel or two of japanese tonkatsu in a panko crust be always nice
make this breaded marvel be easy at home
i cut thin slice from a pork loin and flatten them only a bit
rather than fine dry crumb i prefer to make soft crumb from a day old french loaf cubed and whirl in a food processor which create a coating with a little texture
olive oil be my choice for frying clarify butter or good lard be fine too
make sure the oil be hot but not too hot and do not skimp
you need more than a film of oil in the pan to achieve the perfect color and crunch
season your cutlet both before and after fry it make a difference and serve them as soon as they be ready
i like to scatter a mixture of chop parsley lemon zest and caper over the top along with a sprinkling of chop egg
but a wedge of lemon be all the garnish a well fry cutlet really need
do not forget to administer a good squeeze of lemon juice just before dig in

montclair n.j. glacier an enthralling and important new dance work last 60 minute by the choreographer liz gerring abound in arrest contradiction
the dancer look relaxed and galvanize
they hurl themselves into impetuous slide skim across the stage in nimble footwork push their way urgently backward on all four shimmer in turn or bob jump and yet amid the formal structure always keep an informal quality never let the step acquire any veneer of academicism
step look natural athletic and exploratory even when they then come around a second or third time with other dancer
the work have wit without quirkiness passion without emotionalism its mood change like the weather and its ebb and flow carry aspect of poetry and excitement
this work 's world premiere be give on thursday as part of the peak performances series at the alexander kasser theater at montclair state university where robert wierzel 's design make virtuoso use of the stage
the main area be back by a single white board like a blank cinema screen
this however be just the central panel of an all white triptych so lighted by mr. wierzel that we first wonder if we 're watch mirror effect on either side
this question be further by ms. gerring 's choreography which at time differentiate between the main stage area dance and visible wing space nondance but at other moment let the dance carry on into the wing as if break down boundary and world
the piece be marvelously heighten by michael j. schumacher 's music from which the piece take its title
he incorporate a field recording of sound from a summer sojourn near glacier lake in colorado into a score tap not play live for guitar harp cello clarinet recorder piano and other keyboard instrument
at time pattern of sparse descend two note piano phrase recall debussy 's ãtude we seem close to the flapping of wing an overlap of different instrument suggest not musical harmony but a soundscape of wide multiplicity
pleasure in this work be clinch by how individual ms. gerring 's dancer look and how specifically release by this choreography
i have admire benjamin asriel in work by several contemporary choreographer
here he arrive relatively late in the piece he look newly focus but free
in one phrase as he tip slowly forward on one leg in an arabesque line he become like the needle of a magnetic compass piercingly direct in his adjustment of the angle
brandon collwes best know from his year with the merce cunningham dance company have always dance with a large scale innocence here that quality gain new intensity
step repeatedly onto the ball of one foot in a series of turn but each time tilt his torso way to one side he make you feel in your own body the physic of the step
tony neidenbach adele nickel brandin steffensen jake szczypek jessica weiss and claire westby complete the team change the mood with each entry
entrance and exit be lively ingredient of ms. gerring 's style
often she make compositional joke out of them no sooner bring a dancer onstage than send him off again only to recall him a moment later this time for an extended stay
two woman end a duet with an unforgettable exit
side by side they find themselves hold hand as they jump upward from both foot slowly retreat on a diagonal path it ' the way that they parallel and synchronize in this wonderful image of naã¯vete hover artlessly in each jump that catch the heart
mr. neidenbach a longtime gerring performer of marvelously athletic presence enter by go around in a circle on one side of the stage as he alternately run and walk
that alternation run a half circle then walk another with minimum gear change repeatedly be one of the dance contrast that proliferate in this piece rivetingly
later hauntingly mr. neidenbach cross the stage in one forward skip hopscotch sequence of tiny but top speed step then without miss a beat retreat backward in a big crawling phrase on all four two utterly opposed kind of movement both deliver coolly but excitingly
another beauty of the gerring style be the keen focus she give to her dancer
they do not just do movement they aim it
witness the opening phrase a man and a woman enter together stand and wait look and bend forward
and then simultaneously they turn their eye head and one arm upward and sideways
a simple stroke it at once establish the full three dimensionality of their style
a late motif also basic be a side to side phrase in which the dancer throw up a right arm then step the other way the left arm
the head turn to look at the view the arm have open up
as you watch you sense yourself do it
at first glacier look like a study in stylized pedestrianism flat foot with the dancer show how exactly they perform nonvirtuoso move
but its texture build up and grow complicated
woman then man travel on half toe across the stage jump and turn enter the vocabulary
there be eight dancer though usually few be onstage at any one time it become customary to see several thing go on simultaneously
simple movement remain central as when four man stand in a row face us with arm outspread
one woman enter seem to listen to one man 's heart two other woman unnoticing dance in the background
dancer here be primarily soloist
but partner do occur both same sex and especially opposite sex
there ' a sequence for three male female couple while the geometric patterning be satisfy they at one point correspond to the three screen behind there ' no one moral pattern for male female behavior you see woman lead and support as well as follow and be lift
as glacier deepen and grow in texture it change from a seemingly analytical study into a diverse world
the analytical quality which never vanish add fascination
the diversity add humanity
by scrutinize movement and demonstrate its multifaceted complexity glacier prove not only absorb but also move

sea ice in the arctic ocean undergo a sharp recovery this year from the record low level of 2012 with 50 percent more ice survive the summer melt season scientist say friday
it be the large one year increase in arctic ice since satellite tracking begin in 1978
the expert add however that much of the ice remain thin and slushy a far cry from the thick arctic pack ice of the past
because thin ice be subject to rapid future melting the scientist say this year 's recovery be unlikely to portend any change in the relentless long term decline of arctic sea ice
i 'm not at all surprised there be a jump upward we have never set two record low in a row say walt meier a nasa scientist who have monitor sea ice for year
i would say i be a little surprised the jump be as big as it be
last year 's ice extent be so low that this year 's recovery look large by comparison dr. meier say
the main reason for this year 's growth dr. meier add be that the region be cold and cloudy through the spring and summer than in the recent past
we have cool condition cooler than the long term average and yet it be still go to be the sixth low ice minimum on record dr. meier say
play out over a generation the decline of the arctic ice cap have be one of the most striking effect of global warming a change in the planetary aspect so large it would have be visible to an observer on the moon
we could be look at summer with essentially no sea ice on the arctic ocean only a few decade from now say mark serreze director of the national snow and ice data center in boulder colo. in a statement
contrary to popular impression the melting of sea ice do not cause a rise of sea level since the ice be already float and displace its weight in water
but the replacement of white ice with dark water do mean the surface of the arctic ocean can absorb far more heat in the summer which could contribute to the melting of nearby land ice in greenland raise sea level
during the winter the arctic plunge into near darkness 24 hour a day and a skin of ice grow across most of the ocean surface
but during the summer the sun shin continuously
the key to the status of the ice cap be how much of it survive the summer melt season to become thick resilient ice
when satellite monitoring begin in the late 1970 about half the surface of the arctic ocean would be cover by ice at the end of the melt season which usually occur in september
by last year that figure have fall to 24 percent of the ocean surface rise this year to 36 percent
the national snow and ice data center announce friday that the low point in sea ice this year have occur on sept. 13
the timing vary from year to year and the agency always wait several day before make an announcement to be certain the ice pack have begin to regrow
lately a new low in summer sea ice have be set every few year follow by a few year of recovery follow by yet another low that typically exceed the previous one by a substantial margin

the use of biological marker like fingerprint face and iris to identify people be rapidly move from science fiction to reality
apple 's late iphone which go on sale this week can be unlock with a fingerprint
user of android smartphones can unlock their device with a glance
and the department of homeland security be develop facial recognition technology that would allow it to pinpoint criminal and suspect in large crowd of people with closed circuit camera
once so expensive that it be use only by the military or high tech company biometric technology have become so commonplace that even some school and hospital be use it
its adoption could make sensitive information more secure than conventional identification card or password which can be easily forget lose or hack
but it also have the potential to undermine privacy which have be greatly compromise by recent revelation about government surveillance of phone and internet communication
in fact biometrics be not as safe as be often think
a 2010 report from the national research council conclude that such system be inherently fallible because they identify people within certain degree of certainty and because biological marker be relatively easy to copy
for example people leave their fingerprint on everything they touch which make those fingerprint available to any determine spy or law enforcement agent
expert have show that fingerprint and other marker can be copy give hacker and thief access to private information
and once compromise fingerprint can not be reset like password or replace like passport
if proper safeguard be not put in place the use of some biometrics like facial recognition technology can also be use to conduct intrusive surveillance of individual or group of people by government and private company
use facial recognition software to match database of photo with image from security camera in public space and private building can help law enforcement agency spot and track dangerous criminal
but the same technology can just as easily be abuse to target political activist or protester
retailer could use such system to snoop on their customer shopping behavior so that they could later target specific ad and offer to those customer
facebook already use software to determine whether photo that user upload to the site contain the image of their friend though the company do let user opt out of the system
even as the use of such technology have expand rapidly there have be little public debate about its use
most federal and state law do not directly address the collection and use of biological marker by business and the government
some lawmaker like senator al franken democrat of minnesota have ask government agency and company like apple and facebook to explain how they use biometrics
but congress must do more by enact legislation that govern how this technology be use to make sure it do not compromise privacy right

washington the obama administration 's potentially pathbreaking proposal for carbon emission limit on new power plant will face political and legal challenge from opponent who argue that the technology need have not be close to be prove as the law require
the draft rule be announce on friday at the national press club by gina mccarthy the administrator of the environmental protection agency
but to protect industry from pie in the sky requirement current law limit what rule the agency can make
e.p.a. rule sometimes demand technological advancement but the goal that the agency establish have to be meet by technique that exist law describe as adequately demonstrate
the proposal would limit new ga fire power plant to 1,000 pound of carbon dioxide emission per megawatt hour and new coal plant to 1,100 pound of carbon dioxide
industry official say the average advanced coal plant currently emit about 1,800 pound of carbon dioxide per megawatt hour
a megawatt hour be a little more than a typical american household us in a month
once the rule be in place new plant would be require to capture carbon dioxide from the smokestack and sequester it underground
official say the regulation could be complete by the fall of 2014
but utility say law govern underground disposal be not write with carbon dioxide in mind and sequestration be in a legal quagmire
three system of carbon capture be in various stage of development
the most common be to convert coal into a mixture of hydrogen carbon monoxide which in this context be a fuel not a pollutant and carbon dioxide and to recover the carbon dioxide at two different stage
another method demonstrate by the utility american electric power in recent year at its mountaineer plant in west virginia be to burn coal conventionally and use an ammonia process to grab the carbon dioxide out of the flue ga
and if coal be burn in nearly pure oxygen the flue gas be nearly pure carbon dioxide
in the last few day ms. mccarthy have refer to several early stage carbon capture project as a sign that industry can build the need equipment
in testimony on wednesday before the house energy and power subcommittee ms. mccarthy cite four such project
she tell reporter on friday that the draft rule be base on technology that be already enter the market and be construct in plant today
but the four she refer to in the committee hearing range from under construction to plan
none of them would sequester the carbon dioxide and all would sell it
the close to opening be the southern company 's kemper county plant in mississippi which will convert coal to gas and then filter out some of the carbon dioxide reduce emission by about 65 percent
but the plant at $ 5 billion be $ 1 billion over budget
southern company say in a statement on friday that the plant 's economics be peculiar to its location and not a national model
its capture carbon will be sell for use in the oil field where it help force more oil to the surface
but most power plant be not in area where they can sell their carbon dioxide
revis w. james director of the energy technology assessment center at the electric power research institute say that before a technology could be consider commercially demonstrate you 'd need kemper to be operational and a couple more kempers and have the kink work out
carbon capture and sequestration he say be unlikely to be competitive unless natural ga price increase by 100 to 150 percent and the construction of nuclear plant be rule out
ms. mccarthy also refer to three project that would sell carbon dioxide to the oil industry a coal plant in saskatoon saskatchewan the boundary dam project where the provincial utility plan to rebuild a small 45-year old unit to capture carbon dioxide the texas clean energy project 15 mile west of odessa where the builder hope to soon break ground and hydrogen energy california propose for the oil field of kern county
as the price of oil have rise so have the value of carbon dioxide to oil drillers
the value as a carbon reduction mechanism be unclear though because the result be to produce more oil all of which will be burn produce more carbon emission
e.p.a. official say that a carbon emission rule would push improvement in the technology
two decade ago when the agency require technology to reduce emission of a different pollutant nitrogen oxide a smog precursor that too be expensive and not thoroughly demonstrate but today it be routine they say
the big carbon capture project to date be at the american electric power 's mountaineer plant in new haven w.va
but nicholas k. akins the company 's chairman and chief executive say that technology be definitely not ready for prime time
mountaineer be a pilot project
equip the whole plant would have cost $ 1 billion he say and drive up cost per kilowatt hour by 60 to 80 percent
the company eventually shut down the effort because it could not recover the cost from its customer
and injection of carbon dioxide into the earth be only possible because it be classify as a research project he say

reader discuss the pro and con of telecommuting
â to the editor
be suburban sprawl on its way back
sunday review sept. 15 point out that one reason suburban sprawl may not resume its outward creep be that moderate income family have see their transportation cost balloon to more than a quarter of their income
i remember the many year in which i have a two and a half hour round trip commute to my office job in northern new jersey
it be awful it cost hundred of dollar a month and it be totally unnecessary
today i work at home in western massachusetts make a good living as a freelance writer
i regularly interview source confer with editor and do my work via phone and internet
i travel on business no more than twice a year
mayor michael r. bloomberg of new york be quote in a recent magazine interview say be on a conference call be not the same as stand at the water cooler
it just be n't
and i think you gotta go to work
and i think people should be next to each other to the extent possible
to which i say where ' the evidence that physical proximity to one another help people work better or more creatively
and where ' the evidence that professional be any less productive when they work at home
it ' time for more employer to take advantage of modern technology and allow telecommuting
then people wo not have to choose between have a nice house in the suburb with a long commute and living in an overpriced condo near or in a city
they will live better spend more time with their child and be more productive when they do not have a costly stressful commute every day
and they can work just as closely with their colleague as they can when they 're in the same office
ken terry sheffield mass. sept. 15 2013
the writer be a freelance health care writer and a contribute editor for informationweek
â
reader react
for 12 year people in our company work from home office
for the last year and a half most of us have be work out of an office in manhattan
this experience have convince me that people who work collaboratively work more creatively more efficiently and more productively when in close proximity
some of our employee still work from home and i have notice that they 're often about half a step out of sync with the rest of us because they 're simply not in the flow of day to day operation
yes you can get a great deal do by internet and conference call but not everything that transpire in a company be document in an e mail or a phone call
there ' all that in between stuff the stuff that happen between the idea and the delivery
moreover it ' difficult for an employer to ascertain the productivity of a worker who be not in the office

when dr. john h. kennell be a hospital pediatrician in the 1950 newborn be typically whisk away within minute of delivery wash weigh blood test and plunk into bassinet under the nursery 's fluorescent light
their mother would not be permit to hold them for 12 hour sometimes longer
at university hospital in cleveland where dr. kennell be the staff neonatologist nurse bottle feed infant every four hour
mother could visit but not for very long
dr. kennell who die on aug. 27 at 91 like to say that it be the full throated complaint about this state of affair by his patient that lead him to undertake a research project in the 1960 that help change the world on which most newborn now open their eye
his finding publish in maternal infant bonding a 1976 book write with dr. marshall h. klaus a fellow professor of pediatric medicine at case western reserve university in cleveland be consider a prime catalyst for change in hospital procedure that give new mother more private time with their infant let father into the delivery room and allow young child to visit new sibling in the hospital
the book 's central claim be that infant and their mother be hormonally prim in the first hour after birth to form crucial bond but that under hospital rule then commonly observe that process be not allow to happen
baby be ready to eat right away after be bear but they do not get to their mother for 12 hour dr. kennell say
no one be pay attention to what the baby want
the doctor idea be well receive by developmental psychologist who ascribe to attachment theory which link the relation newborn have with their first caregiver to their ability to have healthy relationship in adulthood
relatively quickly bonding become widely adopt as part of maternity ward routine
but maternal infant bonding come under severe criticism
fellow researcher say its conclusion be base on too small a case sample and put too much stock in the mother child interaction in the first hour
adoptive parent complain that the theory leave them out of the picture
some feminist saw it as just another way to place child rear responsibility solely on woman and to blame the mother if a child grow up troubled
dr. kennell and dr. klaus acknowledge mistake in their finding and publish a revise version of their book in 1982 parent infant bonding
though it stick to the original premise the new edition be less specific about a bonding timetable
the book have be update several time since
in an introduction to the 1996 edition the noted pediatrician author dr. t. berry brazelton defend the author
despite criticism by some that proof of a sensitive period for bonding between parent and baby have not be show the author have continue to fight for a more humane atmosphere in hospital at the time of delivery dr. brazelton write include time for early attachment behavior between a new parent and baby
we now realize how important it be to create this atmosphere
the sea change in hospital childbirth practice draw on many social current of the 1960 and 70 include the natural childbirth movement the woman 's movement and an anti authoritarian climate say j. kevin nugent the director of the brazelton institute a child and family research center found by dr. brazelton at boston children 's hospital

john help change that

berlin it would be easy to mock the political campaign that end with sunday 's national election in germany as a version of fiddle while rome burn
it have lack any heated debate over the nation 's role in maintain the common european currency or address the crippling level of unemployment among its southern neighbor
the clash over intervention in syria that consume the britain france russia and the united states for week barely make a political ripple here underscore how deeply germans shun the use of force
chancellor angela merkel 's center right government and the left lean opposition remain largely united in support an ambitious and costly plan to wean the economy off nuclear power and carbon fuel
there be little talk of the demographic challenge of an age population
it be a showcase for the postwar german tendency toward consensus and be all the more remarkable for the contrast it provide to the bitter ideological clash play out in the united states and many other big democracy
it could well yield an outcome almost unfathomable in peacetime washington paris or london a power sharing agreement between the main party of the left and right
the relative comity between the major party on the campaign trail do not mean that ms. merkel assume she emerge to lead the next government can escape tough choice or that germany can insulate itself from force beyond its control from the financial market and the global economy to tumult in the middle east and a russia that be try to reassert itself
welcome by many germans as stability at a time of prosperity the mood may nonetheless disappoint germany 's allies in the united states who would love to see the country assert itself more in europe as well as its partner in the european union who just want to end the bloc 's doldrums and look to germany for bold action
frustrating as it may be this germany of slow step and consensus politics be precisely the one that the united states and its victorious european allies seek to forge in the smoldering ruin of world war ii.
it be a structure that be reinforce as late as the country 's reunification after the fall of the berlin wall in 1989 when the old german question of how to tame the country 's undoubted power be solve by wrap it still tight in the bond of a unify europe the very one be test today by a slow grind economic crisis
it be also a system that have promote steady and farsighted vision on big issue
more than in most western democracy german leader include ms. merkel who be seek a third term have persuade their people to endure short term pain for long term gain whether reunification energy transformation or a decade ago the kind of labor and economic overhaul that other european nation be still blink at
we be the student very eager to learn the american re education program say jã¼rgen falter 69 a professor at the university of mainz and an expert both on the nazi past and germany 's complex electoral system
and we have really fully internalize it we go for pacifism not belligerence consensus rather than conflict
after 1945 the allies deliberately build a federal structure that disperse power from berlin and scatter national institution throughout what be then west germany
in addition they devise an electoral law virtually guarantee to produce a coalition government no chancellor since konrad adenauer in the late 1950 have be able to govern alone
for proof take ms. merkel of the christian democrats and her main rival peer steinbrã¼ck of the social democrats
numerous domestic and international observer have struggle to detect vibrancy in the back and forth between ms. merkel 's camp and mr. steinbrã¼ck 's over any range of issue child allowance for nonworking mother how best to preserve generally good and cheap health care and even what berlin really intend for the 17-nation euro zone or the 28-member european union
the distinction in their position fall squarely into the two social grouping from which they spring the christian middle class in the case of the christian democrats and the working class and trade union for the social democrats
the center left be more open about the possible need to raise tax give the impoverished state of germany 's municipal and state coffer

this interview with rakesh kapoor chief executive of reckitt benckiser be conduct and condense by adam bryant
q.
what be some important early lesson for you
a. i be bear in a very small town in india and the literacy rate at the time be just one in six
thankfully one of the big thing my parent could do for me be to recognize that if i stay in that town it would be very difficult to get out
and i remember learn how my parent decide that i have to leave
i be play marble and i have an exam the next day
my mother say why be not you study for your exam
and i say what ' the point
i will be first anyway
i be not that bright but in that small town i would have be first
so my parent send me to the no 1 school in india which happen to be a boarding school in new delhi
it immediately change the game for me
i go from somebody who have never be second in class to the middle of the class
the bar be immediately raise and i have to work really hard
the lesson for me be that a very important part of leadership be to set a bar for people and to constantly keep them out of their comfort zone
i think status quo be a real enemy for progress
and get out of my own comfort zone be just as important
q. any other influence from your parent
a.
i ask my mom recently if she saw anything in my early childhood year that would tell her that there be something great in store for me
she tell a story of when i be pretty young and i have some medical problem
she take me to an ayurvedic doctor and he give me a concoction that i have to put on my tongue rather than swallow every day
i would do it every day and not complain
one day my mom try the medicine to see what it taste like
and she say it be the most bitter awful medicine
when she be tell me about this recently she say i think one of the thing about you be that you do not complain about something you have to do
and i think this be a leadership lesson too
you have to swallow many bitter pill in your life
you just can not keep complain about how life should be
you have get to accept the way you have to run your life and then do the very best you can
q. tell me about your first career job
a. i come from a background of entrepreneur and after i get my m.b.a. i join a start up rather than a big company
i find that to be a much more exciting way of learning
i become an area sale manager for an electric typewriter company and i be send to a state call gujarat
we go there and there be nothing
i say to my bos can you even tell me where ' the office
which way do you want me to go
he say there ' no office address
that ' why we hire you to build our business
and for the next couple of year i recruit a huge number of people and we create the second large business of that company
so i tell people that when you choose your first job choose one where you can really make a difference from day 1 rather than get submerge in a big company mind set
it also teach me that if you be go to be successful you have get to treat your company like your very own
because as an entrepreneur you be depend on yourself to create the value not anyone else
you can not rely on other people to tell you what to do
you have get to take the initiative yourself
and if you do that you know you be go to have a great chance of success
q. important lesson you have learn from mentor over the year
a. my previous bos be a very successful c.e.o. he run the company for over a decade and we achieve fantastic result
he teach me many thing but he be immensely focused
time be the only one clear constraint in life and if you focus on a few thing you have a great chance of achieve something interesting
he teach people like me and others who have this burn desire to achieve more and more to prioritize and to be very consistent with the priority
he never change the strategy in 12 year
he focus on a few big thing and go after them

a. you have to take risk

scarcity give rise to more idea than abundance do
scarcity be the mother of invention
i have grow up like that
scale be also the enemy of speed
as you become big you 're go to get slow and slow
so you have to create small team because they be more effective and more efficient than big team
you also have to be careful about how many layer you 're create
